product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: at first it was OK but after a few days of using it, it just broke.....!it is not cheap and yet it is made of a cheap metal....... this is just money waste :(
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: These are almost an exact knock off of a Craftsman model I remember my father had in the 70's/early 80's. Minus the quick release button which now appears on the new Craftsman model too. These work great for building boxes and assembling miter joints. I have already built 3 cabinets and a mirror utilizing these and they worked perfectly. Good clamping strength (for what they are) and easy to setup your angle.I cleaned them with degreaser and clamped some scrap wood. Still ended up with black smudges so I applied blue painters tape to the clamp faces. Not too big of a pain for the value of these clamps.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: These very well made right angle clamp have been in use in my shop for 18 months now, I had read the negative reviews and felt since I have been building "Heirloom Quality" Custom Woodwork for 30+ years, I should add my "2 cents". For someone who knows what a right angle clamp is supposed to be used for , these work very well (I have 10 total) - if your mitered cuts are "dead-on" 45 degrees and being that "end to end grain" joints are the weakest unless a spline(s) or dowel pin(s) are utilized along with high quality wood glue (apply a skim coat first to fill the grain as end grain will soak up the glue) I tape the edges so glue won't fill the open grain on the face and cause spots where stain will not penetrate, if you are expecting these clamps to "pull" a bad cut into place - you should reset your saw or get a miter box, these are for as one other review stated "a extra set of hands" I allow my properly assembled joints to stay in these with a minimum amount of pressure for 16 - 24 hours, they will break if dropped and land wrong (they are cast aluminum and brittle plastic handles) They will also hold a "T" joint in place to allow the glue to set, but still dowel pin or screw the joint - There is no short-cut for quality and I have burned up a lot of time, wood and $$ learning that "experience" is the best teacher, I'm still learning from older and some younger woodworkers- Happy sawdust- and remember "If you love what you do, you will never work a day in your life" Thanks to Amazon for allowing everyone to review the items we all can use to better the space we occupy, and to the reviewers as well
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Look elsewhere if you want to clamp anything larger than small items.
review_text: This clamp has a very limited range where it will work well. As long as the items you're clamping are within the confines of the clamp walls themselves it seems to be able to exert enough pressure to get a good glue bond... say a thin picture frame or such. However if your trying to clamp up anything larger for gluing it just doesn't have the clamping power to to do it.It's extremely cheaply made from the lowest quality materials that could be sourced. Also it wasn't quite square in any direction.Read the bad reviews and believe them, it got two stars because it works just ok on small items.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Great for picture frames, but I've stripped two out of five. UPDATED
review_text: UDATE: I've come up with a workaround and fix for the problem.The workaround is to simply add some material (I used five pieces of mat board stacked) to make whats being clamped wider so that the bad part of the threads aren't a factor.The fix is to disable the quick release button. The real problem is that the bad place on the threads is tripping the quick release so it can't be tightened. When I disabled it by wrapping a homemade spacer around the piston behind the button and taping it in place, the clamp tighten just fine. We'll see how long it lasts.UPDATE:I initially gave these a great review, but now I've had two strip out. Admittedly, I really tweak them building picture frames. That's why I'm still giving them three stars.I build picture frames, and I've struggled with cheap clamps from the local hardware store. I had to mount those on corners made of 1x4s to make them usable, but not these clamps. I uploaded a picture of a frame being glued with both types of clamps used together.  I'm ordering two more of these now so that I'll have two of the setups in the picture. I wish I had eight of these, but that's a little pricey.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: I like this product, because it is like an extra set of hands with built in clamps. I wish that I had bought this clamping jig sooner. I used it for putting together a shelving unit, and it made the job a breeze. The reason I bought this, is to continue building varying woodworking projects. There is no doubt in my mind that I bought a great product.  The clamping force of the product is perfect! Having the screw handle style clamping, really helps to adjust the material you work with; and not wreck your work under too much force. Some people have said that they hate the quick release feature. I have to say, I don't agree with that at all. In fact, I feel as if it makes working with it much better. What's better than being able to quickly release the work when you're done? Especially, if you are cramped for time.  This is hands down, a solid tool. The release buttons look flimsy, as well as the screw handles. Yet, they both work flawlessly. Best purchase for sure!
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: When I first got that tool I was pleased because the frame looked and felt really sturdy.I used it to create one(!) drawer. After assembling the third corner one of the winding seemedto be compromised. When I tried to tighten one side it kept slipping through.My assumption is that there's a flimsy plastic piece in that casing were the winding goes through.Maybe it works for tiny frame building, where you just need that as a kind of loose guide.When you want to tighten two boards in a medium duty, this 90 degree angle is NOT what you are looking for!
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: Before I got this I had a difficult time wrapping my monkey brain around holding two pieces together at a right angle so that I could glue/screw/nail them together flush.Enter this right angle clamp. Not an exaggeration  when I say that all of my woodworking is now easier. You simply push a little red button on either clamp to rapidly move the slide, and then the screws allow you to put some good clamping force on both of the pieces, making them fit nice n' snug.You can mount it on a workbench easily, but I've been doing right angle glue ups on the floor and this thing works great. I highly recommend it.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: Bought two for a basement shelf project.  Things were going great until the third shelf, at which time one of the clamps refused to tighten.  Regardless of what I did, the quick release kept engaging anytime pressure was placed on the clamp to tighten it to the board.  After taking the clamp apart to try to figure out why it was doing this, I noticed the threads on the quick release casting had already started to round over (after less than a dozen uses!!!) and that it would be impossible to fix.  Highly disappointed in the quality of this item and consider this purchase as $50 down the drain!!!
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Works great if you only need to use it 4-5 times
review_text: Depends on your project!Great clamp! Larger capacity than most and worked very well. Why only 2 stars you ask? Well, it only worked great for the first 5-6 joints. Now one side works great, the other won't tighten. As you get it tight on the project, tight enough to hold that is, it jumps threads and is loose again. I tried holding down the push button piece to force it to hold, worked well for one more corner. Now even that won't work.I'm hoping to make it still work by cutting that side off and still being able to use a traditional dewalt clamp to hold wood at the 90 degree angle. Definitely not worth the money though, I could have made a jig for less, just figured this would be more convenient. I'll admit I was wrong, big time.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: My first customer review on anything, ever, but I read them and, frankly rely on them sometimes so here goes.I'm a finish carpenter by trade. I do like these clamps and had the thread slipping problem as so many have mentioned. Disappointing as these aren't what I would call cheap. They are cast aluminum BTW, not painted plastic as mentioned. At least all mine are aluminum.Anyhow, rather than cast off the duds, here's something to try. Sorry, no pics. I'm not that techno savvy.On the back of the slide jaw there's a keeper plate attached by 2 phillips head screws. Remove the screws / plate. The jack screw is held in place by a C clip which is now accessable. Remove the C clip. The Jack screw can now be extracted completely past the thread / spring mechanism.In my case, simply stretching the spring to make it stronger has done the trick. Re assemble. The C clip can be a pain to get on / off but its do-able.I have several of these clamps and have had to do this more than once, but beyond that I find the clamps well made and very useful. I hope this easy fix keeps a few of them out of the trash bin. It's definitely a silly flaw but not a deal kill where the clamp is concernedCheersEditAfter having done this fix several times I became aware that the little square threaded "box" in there is, for some odd reason, directional. Fix, test, flip, fix again...etc. after figuring this out they've been working great since. Years in use, often daily, Rock solid.Too bad there's this little "personality flaw", but in the end these are good clamps. I use them hard. They're also good as a small vice when clamped to a table. Great little clamps. Don't give up on them.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: Perfect for what I need it for...holding boards in place so I can screw them together or drill lined up holes. Used it for a couple projects so far and it works well. A couple other reviews have noted that it doesn't hold "tight" for gluing. It's not supposed to as that's not really what it's for. The description outright states "It's useful function of an assembly aid helps in the alignment and clamping of parts for nailing, welding, and screwing." Key words "assembly aid". I don't see the word "glue" anywhere in the description. If you are looking for a clamp to squeeze boards together for glue joints, look at the Irwin bar clamps. I have several and they are awesome for that (and other things!).I've also seen other reviews stating they twisted and stripped the clamping screw. Not sure how much pressure they were putting on it. My guess would be a lot (perhaps trying to squeeze boards for gluing?). I clamp my boards pretty tight and they don't move. No issues or worries that it looks or feels like it will break or strip.This tool helps you hold things together temporarily so you can fasten them together permanently with something else. For that purpose, it's perfect.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: I bought it and it works fine. I'll be back to give it a review in a month or so.
review_text: I was a little skeptical about this tool. I only used it twice already and the plastic seems very sturdy. It feels very well built, but I don't understand why they used the clamping part for plastic use. I'm hoping this product and tool will last for a good 5 years without having to replace it.Does what it shows and very useful for Butt Joints and whatever joints need to be mounted and screwed. I highly recommend this, but there is also a decent 3D 90* available, but that requires clamps to fit in place.Note: You may need to adjust a little for flush and perfect alignment (also depends if you re-trimmed your wood).
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: Great design, cheaply constructed.The clamp broke while drilling a pilot hole into a wooden leg. The leg moved and kept sliding away from the drill. Turns out the pressure of drilling into wood stripped the screw securing the clamp.This was the third use, and I was drilling into pine.  The clamp is useless now, and will not hold anything securely. Far too expensive for a clamp that won't make it through four legs.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: effective clamp to replace long clamps
review_text: I bought 4 of these to assemble a large bookcase I built recently. They were fairly effective for pulling in a datoed shelf. I found it much more effective to clamp tight on the shelf with some gap between the inside of the clamp and my outer board. Then I pulled in the shelf with the perpendicular clamp.For another project, I used the clamps to make a connection on the outside edge if a 90° corner. I glued and doweled the first corner without first checking if it was square. Turns out it was at least a 1/4" out of square over 2'. I managed to pull everything back into square on the other corners to remedy, but I spent a lot of time lining up and squaring off adjusting to get things perfect. I don't know if the tension from the off corner made it more difficult or if getting an exact 90 will require this much adjustment every time. I think this has to be as good as clamping to a square, but it wasn't trivial.Overall, I am very satisfied with this purchase. The construction of the clamp seems robust. The quick adjustment is convenient for quickly adjusting as long as there wasn't tension. The handles are plastic. Hopefully, they will hold up. The one thing that was disappointing is the clamps left significant black marks where they were tightened down. My bookcase had to be finished in sections with final assembly in place. I used some T-shirt rags under the clamps to prevent marring on the polyurethane finish. It was a bit of a pain, but worked out. My other strait clamps didn't have that problem.The clamps also have to be located on the outside of the corner. I have staggered shelves on my bookcase which prevented use of the clamps where clamping onto a square could have been easily done.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Great clamp and plenty useful in the shop.
review_text: Bought this in addition to one I already had.  Have been doing some woodworking projects including building picture frames and this is one really useful tool.  Only issue I had was (having only one) I had to glue up two sections of frame at a time then (when the glue was dry) build up another set and finally attach the two sections with one end unclamped.  Now I can build both sections, let dry and complete the frame holding both corners for glue up.  The advantage is that your corners will be exactly 90 degrees with no misalignment and a perfect miter joint in all four corners.  Lots of room in case you want to drive a wire brad or two while in alignment as the tool has space for driving the brad.Invaluable for making precise, professional looking picture frames!  Only criticism is that the clamp should be sold in a set of 2 (maybe with a little discount).  Highly recommended!
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Well made but not as easy to use or effective as other types of clamps.
review_text: I'm rating the clamps effectiveness and ease of use, not its quality of manufacture.  It was cumbersome to use compared to another type of clamp I ended up using instead. It just didn't get the corners tightly together without a lot of effort on my part.  It actually seemed to be very well made and I would give it a 5 on that metric.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Very Well Constructed - Perfect for gluing up Corners
review_text: I have seen a lot of styles for the 90° (aka Right Angle) clamps, this is probably one of the best out there. They are constructed very well, even the jaws have a rubber pad to protect the work - which is replaceable, I ordered 4 of them, and i have tested them out with some sample work - excellent ... more than I expected as far as quality and ability. If you require right angle clamps then these are the ones you want. Remember .. new designs don't always mean they work or work better. This is a simple turn screw style design and " It Works." I recommend these clamps to anyone requiring a right angle clamp - buy them you will not regret it.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: An inexpensive, solidly built tool that works well.
review_text: A solidly built tool, well worth $20. The clamp is made of heavy gauge metal with sturdy hardware and the base is slotted for mounting it to a bench or jig. The handles are nice and large, have a comfortable grip, and move smoothly.The quick-adjust buttons are an excellent feature- no more turning and turning and turning to tighten the clamps, just press the button, slide the clamp into position, and release the button. A turn or two is all that's needed to tighten it up at that point.Although it's not really made for it, the clamp is built heavily enough that you could apply some serious pressure if necessary.All in all, this is a great clamping tool, very well made, and absolutely worth the $20 price.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: The screws stripped within a week of buying, could no longer become tight. I had to return. would not recommend.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: I love the idea of this clamp. It would do a nice job of holding two workpieces together for gluing/screwing/nailing.  On my first project, however, one side of the clamp stripped. If it strips, though, it has no clamping force.

review_text: I use this clamp for making window frames, boxes, picture frames, it does as it says it does. My only wish is that it came in 3.5" width for bigger stock, as I often use material 3.25" to 3.5"

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: I bought these thinking I can use them to square up some projects I have in mind, including some drawers and such. I finally got around to using them for the first time and once the pieces were clamped in placed I checked for square. Not even close, instead of fighting the clamps, I eyeballed it and got them much more square. It seems the pads themselves arent very square, one gets thicker torwards the top and another is thicker on one side. I may try to sand them square in the future but not what I paid for. I gave it 2 stars simply because the housing is pretty solid so far.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Thing works so I bought another one!
review_text: The nice part about it is, you can use it for woodworking, or metalworking! I would not get too close to the clamp with welding though, as the clamps are made aluminum with plastic handles, but it will definitely hold a 90° angle so that you can throw on the TAC Wells. Or weld up half the project. Let it cool and work the other side. It's not designed to put any pressure on your project, it's only designed to hold everything in place at a 90° angle. I am currently building a queen-size headboard, and the firebox for my barbecue pit, and this has worked fine for both of those.

review_text: This clamp is a great tool for making 90 degree corners. The arms are long enough to give excellent support. The heavy duty construction keeps the joint rigid and provides substantial clamping force. The size of the clamp limits their use to larger projects. I use my clamps mainly for furniture and cabinets to ensure accurate 90 degree corners. You won't be disappointed with these clamps.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: The extra set of hands you need.
review_text: These clamps are great. I just finished a set of built-in bookcases, and these clamps came in very handy. I built them by myself, with some help from my wife, and I would have had a much more difficult time without them.They were superb in that I could dry fit the case to mark where the biscuits needed to go without any help.When it came time for glue-up, the same applies. They kept the cabinets at right angles until I could get proper clamps and screws done. They don't get in the way, yet are very strong. The all metal construction makes them very sturdy - better than plastic ones. You can also mount them to a work surface at the appropriate dimensions and really churn through the operation. I didn't use it, but they are engineered to let you work a miter while the pieces are clamped up.I won't build another set of cabinets without them. Well, because I own them, but if I didn't have them, I would buy again.

review_text: Purchased this for wood work, but I had a welding job and didn't have a welding clamp, so tried this and it worked great.  I'm surprised it is so strong.  It's easy to adjust, and held the work at a right angle, while I tacked it and then removed the clamp to complete the weld so it wouldn't overheat.  Very versatile clamp,  I haven't used it for a 2X4 yet, but it seems large enough and sturdy enough to make a good pocket screw joint.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: The Good:  I had originally bought a few of these from Harbor Freight since they were very cheap in price.  Of course though, they were cheap in much more than price.  After getting frustrated on a few projects, I went ahead and bought four of these clamps.  They are very high quality and get the job done much better than the cheap imitations.The Bad:  I wish more of this product was made of metal.  Instead, the push bottom releases are plastic.  While this hasn't been a problem, I can see them wearing out after a while.

review_title: A satisfactory substitute for having 4 hands
review_text: The biggest improvement I wish for is an angle clamp that could also apply pressure to the joint.  As it is, this clamp is like having an extra pair of hands to hold things in place while you fit bar clamps in place, drive nails or screws, etc.  I have found it extremely helpful to have four of the things, so I can have all four corners of a box or carcase held in place and all on the same level.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: After dealing with cheap corner clamps for years, all I can say is "wow!" At $20 each, it is not easy to spring for a set of these unless you do a lot of woodworking. However, once you take the plunge, I doubt you will be disappointed. I bought 4, and am already wanting 4 more, to enable properly building one whole box (speaker cabinet, etc.) at a time.The only criticism I have is that the width of the clamp edge could be increased. Though I am sure that is designed as-is for good reason. If you were building frames rather than boxes, a wider grip might get in the way.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: I would have given this 4 or 5 stars, but after a few uses, one of the internal springs that holds tension on thequick release buttons lost elasticity so that the clamp wouldn't tighten. I wrote to Wolfcraft for a new spring, but never received a response. When working, the clamp is great.  Perhaps mine was just an anomaly, but I probably will steer clear of this brand in the future.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Works Excellently and Saves Time and Tears of Frustration
review_text: Used this to make 2 x 4 stud frame walls for a basement storage project. It saved a lot of time squaring things up as we build the walls and kept the 2x4s matched and aligned. Invaluable! Releases and clamps very well, but the red release buttons don't work very well when the clamp is under tension. Not a big deal, and the bottom line is that this works well and saves a great deal of time and frustration.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: These clamps are pretty good, but they're not nearly as durable as I would hope. The quick release on one failed (making it impossible to clamp with any force) and was replaced promptly by Wolfcraft (their customer service is really great). On my second the connection between the threaded rod and the clamping face has come apart. I could probably have it replaced, but it's not worth the hassle. I think, were I to make the purchase again I would instead go with a good band clamp and maybe some clamping squares.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: The product is as advertised - heavy duty and well constructed. I was using Spax screws so didn't have to drill pilot holes, but if I had, I could have with no fears that there would be slippage. I wish I had had these for other projects.Handles 2" thick lumber with no issues.Very good - happy to have them.

review_title: Good enough for the money. A novice review...
review_text: I bought two of these for my newest "hobby." I could probably have gotten along with just one, however it is here if needed. I like the fact that I can (now) connect two pieces of wood at a 90 degree angle with repeatability. Prior to this purchase, it was a "good enough" procedure. It is difficult as of this first use review, though, to gauge the alignment of the clamp for clamping my work; frustrating, as I have used many other tools in my life, none of them for woodworking. I am happy to have these; the quality, however, is suspect. I have used enough substandard tools to recognize them. I am a (new) hobbyist, so I feel that I will not expose any inherent weakness during my infrequent use. I would purchase this product again.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: when it works, it is a great product. Mine stopped working after 3 months. one of the handles stuck and can not be adjusted, which makes it useless.update on Augst 7, 2012: I called the company and complained about the problem (they have 5 years warranty). They sent me a replacement free of charge. In the meanwhile, I investegated the one that stopped working. It was found out the moving part was too tight on the track that got stuck. It could be adjusted again if I use hand to move the moving part instead of using the handle. After receiving the replacement, i found the new one does not have the same problem. I guess they made improvement on either production or QC. I would upgrade it to FOUR stars.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: I had used the Wolfcraft 3415405 Right Angle Clamp pretty regularly for building different pieces of furniture and cabinet ...
review_text: I bought this angle clamp in January 2015 AND here it is June 8, 2016 posting my review. I normally hold off on writing reviews on tools I buy for this very reason. I had used the Wolfcraft 3415405 Right Angle Clamp pretty regularly for building different pieces of furniture and cabinet frames, but about 4 months ago I started having issues with the lock on the clamp not holding. It looks to be well build and it’s a good design, but there may be an internal screw broken that keeps the clamp from tightening. If you know anything about woodworking, this is NOT GOOD. The reason for clamps is to hold your pieces tight for gluing or nailing or cutting. When this product worked in 2015 is was great, but not long after I now have a right angle clamp that does not work. I would NOT BUY THIS PRODUCT….look for a different right angle clamp. THIS THING DID NOT LAST and this type of tool should be built to last for longer than 14 months!Very Disappointed,Ben

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_text: The price was good and the shipping was relatively fast.  Theses right angle clamps make squaring work easier and faster.  You can use the Pythagorean Theorem (length (squared) + width (squared)= x(squared), which is the hypotenuse angle or in this case the diagonal from corner to corner)). Then find the square root of "x"(squared) to determine the diagonal length (hypotenuse) to calculate what the length squaring should be.I've read some posts that just mention squaring the cabinet but if the carcase needs to be 30" tall and 20" wide, make sure you square it to the results of the Pythagorean Theorem's calculations.  If the results for a 86" x 36" closet carcase is 236.806cm (or 93.23"), then you diagonal measurements for square on the carcase should be just that, 236.806cm (or 93.23").  I prefer using the metric system so I don't have to do more math to figure out what .23 is or where it is on my tape measure, and no, you can't use 1/4" nor 3/16" because it lies in between the two.  In fact, it lies very close to 15/64", which is very good for cabinet work!  Centimeters and millimeter are MUCH easier to find and convert to each other, just move the decimal point to the left or right one space and round off, so 236.806 could be 236.8 or 236.81, which are easier to measure using a metric tape measure!  Don't just come up with whatever the tape measure reads and if you're within 1/8th, then you're good-to-go.  NO!  You're not good-to-go!  Don't try to just make numbers match (if they're not the correct hypotenuse angle length).  Calculate what the hypotenuse, long angle, or diagonal square dimension should be and shoot for that number.  Shoddy work will come back to haunt you, especially with moving parts like drawers and pullouts.  If you're doing frameless work, your work will show up as quality work or as crap, trust me.  If your cuts are square, then you won't have any problems, but the assembly must be square as well (even square cuts could end up a parallelogram).Just use these right angle clamps as a jig (once you calculated the hypotenuse angle) and secure the jigs onto your workbench or build table to that dimension (in my example, 236.806cm (or 93.23").  After that, simply insert the lumber into the clamp and the assembly will be square (because the placement of the clamps is square, so anything attached to the clamp will be square).  No need for having to rack into square or trying to beat the glue time.  Jigs are helpful for these reasons and all your cabinets will be the exact same dimensions (barring bowed, cupped, or unplaned plywood to begin with).  Usually, if you have quality plywood to begin with and cut everything square, the jigs will provide a mechanical means of "square" for you.If I need any more woodworking tools, I'll surely consider shopping here again.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Use it for alignment while drilling
review_text: I use these for aligning and holding two boards together while drilling holes for screws. They work great for that!All you need is a hand drill and these clamps plus a decent drill bit.If you use wood screws, use a tapered bit.If you use drywall or "multi-purpose" screws, then just drill a slim pilot hole.If you use machine screws, then use a self tapping bit.If you are "directionally challenged," ( meaning; you can't drill straight) then use a drill guide.Even if your holes are a little off, the boards will come together straight because they were aligned when you drilled the holes.I have used these for aligning all sorts of work: casework, cabinets, fences, shelving, jigs & fixtures, tool-box carcasses... you name it.You need two of them. That's no problem since they are usually sold in pairs.BTW, you will save a little money (about 25% to 30%) if you do buy them packaged in pairs.Having raved about these for this purpose, I must point out: they are not that great for actually clamping during glue-ups. They are not designed to bring corners together. They are designed to hold corners in place. So, just be aware of that. If you use screws to bring edge-joints together, then these are great. If you are trying to apply clamping pressure, you need another system.Think of them as an extra pair of hands that hold things squarely. Use them for that purpose and you won't be disappointed.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: DO NOT crank the handle down too hard like I did because at the end of the threaded ...
review_text: Well, I used it only once before it broke. It held boards together well and from my first check of the angle at which it held 2 boards, it seemed to be truly 90 degrees. But, DO NOT crank the handle down too hard like I did because at the end of the threaded rod there looks to be a weak spot on the end where it is attached to the corner bracket that clamps on the inside of the boards you’re trying to hold in place. It sucks because I really was excited about it. So, I’m giving 3 stars because how fragile that connection point.
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Awesome.  Have used these for years.
review_text: I own 2 of these.  Have for 10 years.  Love them.  I use them for welding, woodworking.  They're a little expensive, but well worth it.  If I could change anything though, it would be to make the parts replaceable so that when I melt the plastic part with my welder I don't have to buy all new.

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Flawed mechanism combined with an unhelpful manufacturer/distributor
review_text: I unfortunately purchased this at a B&M store and didn't have the benefit of the reviews here.  I also made the mistake of purchasing it in advance of a project and not testing it out for a while.  When I did use the clamp, within a few applications, I ended up with the same "stripping" issue as the others have already noted.  The process of tightening one of the clamps somehow engages the quick release button, which promptly releases the clamp (making it feel like it's stripped).  I reached out to Wolfcraft, who redirected me to the Mibro Group (the North American Distributor), who refused to replace the product under warranty, because I did not retain the receipt.  I pointed out that I am happy to send the faulty clamp, which is clearly brand new, and we're talking about a known, recurring design flaw with their product.  But no luck.  Lesson learned (shop with an electronic trail so you don't have to worry about a paper receipt later).
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps

product_title: wolfcraft 3415405 Quick-Jaw Right Angle 90 Degree Corner Clamp
review_title: Turning the otherwise piece of crap into a real working tool!!!
review_text: Wolfcraft makes this product as well as a vise to be used on a drill press. Both have the identical "quick release" mechanisms.I have one of these vises. The thread crapped out within a few days...... but I don't give up easily.Here is what to do to turn the Wolfcraft products using this "quick release" mechanism from a piece of useless crap into working the way they should.The cost of the modification is probably less than a cent.Here is the mod.1. Remove the red "quick release" button by simply pulling it out with your fingers or a flat screwdriver. You may not need to even remove it.You will fully expose the rectangular plunger used to activate the release.2. Take a 5/64 drill bit and make sure the release is fully OUT ie not depressed.3. Drill a hole in the soft metal with the hole being as close as possible to where it enters the mechanism. Go straight through the block.4. Clean up and drop a small nail into the new hole.5. It will never strip out again. Simply pull the nail out when you want to use the "QR" button.6. Problem solved and NOW its a useful tool!!!!You are welcome!!!
category: Tools, Home, Improvement, Power, Hand, Tools, Hand, Tools, Clamps, Angle, Clamps
