review_text: As someone suffering with major depression it is so nice to finally hear something that I can relate to. The music is so light and tropical? The lyrics really remind me of Morrissey, Talking Heads, and other kind of edgy yet fun New Wave artists of the 80s and early 90s. I swear there are even some lyrics where she refers to some of their lyrics (Dreaming by Blondie). Anyway, I love it. It's nice to hear that someone else has the exact same types of thoughts that I have about life right now as a late twenty something.

review_title: Happy and Sad packed into 10 songs
review_text: Upbeat depression. Life is great.

First off, this vinyl was so visually appealing (I have the white marble version) and it is hard for me to keep my hands off of it, because the marble looks just that good- very real and beautiful, like an actual marble counter that I wanted to slide my hands across. This is one of my favourite album designs since the (almost completely) translucent Vessel vinyl by twentyonepilots (an excellent group also signed to FUELEDBYRAMEN liked Paramore). Okay, so for the actual review of the product? The folder style album holder is very well constructed, feels durable, and gives plenty of eye candy. And once I got to the music, it was clear that this album was worth every. single. penny. Now, I have to admit: when the first song began, I thought I had somehow put on the wrong album, because their sound has changed significantly, but if there were ever a time when change was a good thing, this would be that time, hands down. I loved their old sound and I still do, but what they managed to do on this album is phenomenal and if you aren't paying attention, you almost miss it. Paramore managed to outdo themselves after albums like Riot! and Paramore. While this is not the kind of rock I was expecting, it is exactly Paramore's style and resonates with me on such a deep level. The music has a Rock SynthPop vibe, a depressed, pessimistic rocker meets Hawaiian Getaway feel and the juxtaposition between light-hearted tones and vibing jams & deep, haunting lyrics creates tremendous pieces of music. In fact, the uplifting tone of the music, itself, betraying the tone and message of the songs is a device they use that can easily be overlooked. It allows that, while on the outside someone may play the part of the happy-go-lucky kid for you guys (the plucky music), in reality, they are tired and they are sad (the lyrics revealing the true nature of the song). Hayley says it best, herself, “I'm so fake happy.” This choice to have upbeat, cheerful music that does not match the mood of the songs reflects the mood and “message” of the album, at least that's how I interpreted it. Hard Times, Fake Happy, Told You So, and Rose Coloured Boy are my top favourite four songs from this album, but the entire album is full of bangers and jams that will make you throw your arms up and dance while simultaneously throwing you into an existential depression. A+ content. I feel like this album is definitely on par with the best of their past discography and resonates deeply with a lot of people. I bought this album after hearing a 6 second video that had just 5 seconds of audio from Hard Times in it, and I immediately bought the album without listening to the whole song OR listening to any of the rest of the album, because when I heard that THAT sound was Paramore and that THOSE lyrics were backed by that sound, I wanted to experience it all in one sitting from a vinyl record, regardless of if the album was good or not. My friend said it was a risky gamble at best and a foolish purchase at worst, especially since it was vinyl. "They love to say they told me so," but it's not gambling if it's a sure thing, and in my long experience with Hayley and Paramore, they are ALWAYS a sure thing.
This album released in a perfect time, I needed  fresh, cool music with a meaning and this is it, LOVE IT couldn't be more happier :)

I used to listen to Paramore's older stuff when I was younger, and had a bit more teenage angst. As I grew up, I drifted away from punk/pop-punk music, and didn't really find myself playing their albums as often as I used to. However, when this came out, I figured I'd at least give it a listen. I'm extremely glad I did.After Laughter is definitely a different direction for the band, and the album is heavily influenced by 80's pop. I don't love every song on the album, but some of them really shine. As a collective musical ensemble, the album is incredibly cohesive and flows really nicely. The juxtaposition of upbeat instrumentals and depressing lyrics makes for an album that seems a little more "grown up". This album demonstrates a lot of the versatility of the band, and while I wasn't expecting to love this album, I ended up buying it on CD and listening to it frequently. Definitely recommend.

I love paramore and this  album is different from their previous ones. I love how they chose a different style of music for this album!!! However there is only on thing I was a little upset about..... the color was not the one I expected, on the album it said white marble but I got a black marble with grey. Don’t get me wrong it’s still very pretty I was just expecting the white one.

review_title: Bands Change, Time Goes On: Get Over It
review_text: Paramore received a lot of accusations of selling out on this record, but I don't think that's true at all. Simply switching genres doesn't indicate selling out; only following trends and a severe drop in quality of the lyrical content do. While Paramore certainly isn't the first band to go 80s synth-pop, they didn't seem to be doing it just due to the trend; it felt genuine, and the lyrics were just as well written and meaningful as before. I personally feel it would be more of a sellout move for them to continue making records like RIOT! or brand new eyes, since that would just be pandering to their already established fan base. It was a pretty big risk to pull a complete 180 like that. Also, another thing we have to remember is that Taylor just writes songs differently than Josh. Their past two re it's a have sounded so different fron their previous work for this very reason. I personally loved this album. I'm a sucker for happy, upbeat songs with depressing lyrics, and this album was full of that. From all-out bops like Rose Colored Boy to heartfelt acoustic numbers like 26, this album is amazing. I highly encourage you to to into this album with an open mind, and try not to compare it to their previous albums. It's great in it's own right, and shouldn't be looked down upon due to the stark differences between it and its predecessors.

Not Paramore's best album or anything but still good. Not a lot of guitar work but some is still present. This album is pop mostly. Some good songs too but not what everyone is going to be expecting from the band. The production is generally upbeat but Paramore is still airing out sadness. Not a bad purchase just not a lot of guitar work here. Recommended.Favorite song: "Forgiveness"4.3 stars. 🌟

review_title: Fantastic acidic and introspective songwriting, cleverly disguised as new wave pop music.
review_text: Fantastic acidic and introspective songwriting, cleverly disguised as new wave pop music.  There are some great tracks here including "Hard Times" and "Fake Happy."  I am new to Paramore, but found this album by following Twitter posts from Jason Isbell, John Mayer, and Ryan Adams.  Give this a shot, it does not disappoint and gets better the more you dig into the lyrics.

I have never listened to Paramore much because they fell into the category of "complaint rock" in my opinion.  There was always something about their sound that made me curious and there were a few songs that I liked - most notably "The Only Exception" - but I was never moved to buy an album.  That changed when I heard the single, "Still Into You".  It was such a happy, fun song that I couldn't help but check out the album.  When I did, I was sold.  This album is definitely a new attitude for Paramore, something they readily admit and are a little nervous about.  I am sure some of their devoted fan base will miss the old anger but I do not and I am sure many others will be pleased by the refreshingly fun feel to these tracks.  My favorite track is "Hate To See Your Heart Break" which is one of the least "fun" tracks but I just can't say enough about it.  It gently falls on your ears like soft rain at the end of a long, hot day.  It is a true breakup lullaby.  I also especially like the infectiously driving track "Fast In My Car" and the hilarious "(One Of Those) Crazy Girls" but I find the entire album well crafted and really enjoyable all the way through.  We all know how rare that is.  I personally feel this album is a candidate for the best album of the year.

Great album, don't expect the usual more upbeat lyrics, it's edgier and has raw real lyrics some to melodies that are more upbeat reminiscent of 80s some that are slower or almost grunge like rock based. I don't skip past songs and I actually like the difference, it's real and relatable. I wasn't dissapointed but if you are the type that doesn't like change than this may not be your thing. I'd recommend it.

review_title: Great Pressing with Attention to Detail
review_text: This record, although thinner and more lightweight than most vinyl releases today, sounds fantastic. The black & white marble coloring turned out really nice and doesn’t look awkward like some colored records do. The outer/artwork sleeve is a matte cardboard finish, and the art doesn’t look pixelated. It also comes with two sleeves, one that is a standard poly-lined sleeve you see on most nice record releases nowadays, and one sleeve that looks like a mockup of the ones used with older records. If you enjoy this album and own a turntable, this is worth buying.

First of all, this vinyl is beautiful. The marbled look is very elegant and it’s definitely something you’d want to display. Second of all, besides the vinyl alone, After Laughter is a work of art. Although it came out a few years ago, AL has a special place in my heart. I’m glad this vinyl has found its way into my home. The only thing I have to note is that the casing feels like recycled paper/thin cardboard instead of the hard laminated type.

review_title: Arguably the best album I've bought in a while
review_text: When I found out Paramore had dropped a new album I knew I had to get it because I really enjoyed their older stuff. At first listen I didn't really know what to think of the album because it didn't sound like Paramore of the "Riot!" days. It wasn't what I was expecting and I waited a few days and listened again with different expectations. That listen made me realize it is actually an extremely solid album, just with a different but just as good sound, possibly even better in ways. I'd definitely say this year it has been the best album I've bought, definitely worth the money. The more I listen to it the more I like it, there aren't really too many poor songs on the album which was one of the things I liked about "Riot!" I can actually listen to the whole album without skipping songs. Looking forward to more of their music.

Haley Williams is commited to self-reliance,  isn't angry anymore,  and not only accepts but embraces the real world in her latest victory.  The only weakness the album has in my opinion is that it is somewhat understated - I would love to hear her belt out the vocals the way she did in the song "Decode".  There will be some who cannot accept the toned-down Paramore,  but the songs are still of very high quality;  I would describe Haley Williams as one of the best women songwriters of our time.  The punk feel has been replaced by alternating versions of pop and rock,  with some influences from other musical works - a gospel choir, ukuleles.  At times it is as soft as a Suzanne Vega album,  but not usually.  Songs I would rate lower than a B-:  none.  A+ song: "Ain't It Fun".  Songs to consider downloading if you don't want to commit to the full album:  "Fast In My Car", "Grow Up", "Daydreaming", "Ain't it Fun", "Part II", "Still Into You", "Anklebiters", "Proof", and "Hate to See Your Heart Break".  I would bet that most Paramore fans will embrace the new,  more mature version of the band.  But for those who can't, I understand - I was never able to accept the new Metallica either.  Stay in love with music!
This album is amazing! More pop than rock but that is ok because it is done extremely well. I love this album a little bit more every time I listen to it. Highly recommend.

Cannot believe this came out last year. I’m not a big fan of 80’s sound but putting dark lyrics and happy beats made this a very incredible record. I cannot stop listening to it for 2 mos. now. The band really outdid themselves this time and Taylor York did a very good job on co producing this album. Out of the box thinking with the bands sound.

When Paramore released their single, Hardlines. I was skeptical about this album. The change in sound direction deviated so far from what I had once knew as a pop-punk band. I still had hope. So I listened through the entire album and I ended up hooked. With the entire album put on a loop I had a hard time turning it off. There happened to only be a single song that I had to skip over and I almost can't even justify it as a song. "No Friend" is supposed to be an "outro" to Idle Worship and on my first listen, I thought it was. However, when I realized it was it's own song, I sighed a sigh of relief and removed it from my playlist outright.Overall, this album is super enjoyable to listen to even with this new sound.

review_title: This CD is amazing, but I do have some comments as a fan.
review_text: I have loved Paramore since I first heard All We Know Is Falling. I have been listening to them for over 5 years now and I adore them. The CD is wonderful. The front cover image is cool, and the CD itself is a beautiful matte black. As for the music, if you are a fan and would like to know another fan's take on the album, this is mine:I personally love every song. Some people are saying that they don't like it because it's more upbeat than they are used to, but I like this touch of Paramore. A lot of their songs are very sad or very serious, and a lot of the songs on this album are very cute and upbeat. Especially their new hit, Still Into You. I love this song. I think it's cute and honestly, I don't think saying it's cute is a bad thing. I think that with the loss of the Farro brothers in the bad, a change was necessary and inevitable.When people complain that they "miss how the band used to be" I don't really understand that. Bands, just like all people on this planet, need to be able to grow, explore, and change. If any band were to stay the same through their whole career, there would be no career because no one would listen to their music due to the fact that it would be repetitive. Paramore has gone through a change, and I think it's a wonderful one. I cannot wait until they release more albums so I can collect all of those too (:

I really good album from Paramore. Although it's not like their old sound, I still love their music. I love them just as much as I did when they first started (: The only complaint I have is on the actual vinyl itself. On side B, there appear to be scratches/indentations on the grooves. It doesn't affect the music at all, it still plays quite normally. There's just a slight "flit" or soft static kind of noise in the background whenever it passes under the needle. It's not too noticeable until I inspected the actual vinyl. Just a bit irritating. I've bought a couple other vinyl records from here in perfect condition, and this is the first album I've had a complaint about. Despite this however, I'm happy I picked this up

review_title: have they ever released an album that wasn't good? This album has a different sound that reflects ...
review_text: Paramore does it again. Seriously though, have they ever released an album that wasn't good? This album has a different sound that reflects on the growth that Hayley has had these past few years. The lyrics are relatable and I find myself listening to this album over and over.

review_title: a great mix of new wave vibes and your typical paramore ...
review_text: a great mix of new wave vibes and your typical paramore flavor to create something a bit new. hayleys vocals are strong as ever even if the lyrics as a whole are quick melancholy. overall a great sounding record with terrific production

Only giving it 4 stars because the “black and white marble” was murky looking and blended together into a haze instead of the classic marble look. Otherwise, loved the sound, loved the album, and everything arrived in one piece.

My favorite release so far in 2013. If you have been browsing Pitchfork for the last 20 years; not possible but  go with the metaphor,this recording is going to seriously mess with your mind.Paramore packs a phrase, note, or vocal inflection from a hundred different other recordings into almost every track. They sound totally fresh and original, because they have absorbed their musical roots, and turned it into their own creations, but to me, every song is like living in multiple alternate musical universes at the same time.So each song evolves, slowly,  as you sort out the influences, but they sound great from the first play.

I love the 'new' sound to Paramore.  Bright, happy music combined with deep, painful lyrics really works so well in this album.  They've gone through so much heartbreak as a band over the last several years, and it's produced such a powerful album.

This is the first Paramore album I've ever bought, so I can't compare it much to old ones. I really enjoy this album. The first time I listened to it, I was only into about half the songs. A couple stood out to me right away, but that was all. After listening to the whole thing for the second time, I enjoyed every single song on the album. I feel like this album is going to grow on me even more, each time I listen to it. Their lead single "Into You" is the most pop-sounding this album gets. The rest of the songs on the album are much more rock which is great.

I've been a huge (did I say huge? I meant GIGANTIC) Paramore fan since their inception in 2005. As many other fans have noticed, Paramore has no one definite sound. Sure, Hayley's signature voice can be detected in any song by even the slightest fan, but in all honesty, every single one of their albums had a different overall feel to it. This album is no different.I know that some people were put off because the songs on this album sound more Pop than Rock, but if you're a music fanatic (like me) and are able to hear the beauty in all music, you will be able to hear the riffs and melodies that you've become so accustomed to.It's an amazing album. The songs are deeply personal, describing and referencing to the departure of the Farro brothers. Songs like Ain't it Fun and Movin' On are super fun to sing to, although they may surprise you with the raw, unyielding emotion that is displayed.Overall, if you are someone who enjoys good music, or, if you're a Paramore fan that is curious to hear what all the fuss is about, this album is definitely for you.

Not your old style Paramore, but the most of the songs are catchy. You can feel the emotion in most of the songs. I wish this album was out a year previously as it would have greatly helped me with similar situations! Guess we went through it at the same time.

review_title: New isnt always bad. Give it a chance, you will not regret it.
review_text: Raw, honest album with powerful lyrics and a nostalgic 80s feel that is still unmistakably Paramore. 26 had me bawling and Fake Happy felt too real at times.

Paramore delivers with their forth studio Album! It's slightly different yet at te same time it's still Paramore. A lot of songs are upbeat & positive, and some like "Last Hope" are even inspiring and helpful to many.I love the fact that they decided to write a continuation of "Let The Flames Begin", as I loved that song. "Part II" is that continuation. It starts off with lyrics "What a shame we all remain such fragil broken things, a memory remains, butterflies with punctured wings". It's epic as I rarely see a continuation to a great song, let alone have it be as an amazing of a song as the first or even better!Paramore's music is getting better and better. This album is proof of that. The message in this album seems to be that life can be hard at time and you might feel broken but you're holding on and pullin through (you just "gotta let it happen") and remember that true friends stick around, those that leave were never really true friends.All I can say is BUY THIS ALBUM! You won't regret it!

review_title: ... color and the coloring it did come with looks like dust on black vinyl
review_text: Mine didn't come as pictured color and the coloring it did come with looks like dust on black vinyl, very bleh. As far as the music goes great album and the sound quality is just swell, no complaints there; just very disappointed with the color even after ordering it twice same thing, good luck getting the beautiful white copy.

review_title: Not quite what I was hoping for, but still quality.
review_text: I'm a fairly dedicated Paramore fan, so I suppose I let them get away with more than a band I was on the fence about. That being said, this album isn't the same Paramore sound I've grown to love. Haley Williams isn't so much the star of the show anymore, her vocals are normalized with the music a bit more than previous albums. I also miss the melancholy, but still upbeat sound that they had. This album sounds a bit brighter overall than "Riot!" or "Brand New Eyes." I give it four out of five, because it's still largely a classic Paramore album, but just that little difference in feel has me rating it behind "Riot!" and "Brand New Eyes" in my ranking of Paramore albums.

I love this album. To be honest, I used to be one of the people that didn't like it because it was so different from the music Paramore has released before. But the sad lyrics contrasting with upbeat 80's rock/pop is what pulled me in. The past year has been rough for me, and this album perfectly exudes what I am feeling. I want to cry and dance at the same time. It's perfect.

Product came in perfect condition.  I am a huuuuge fan of Paramore, and I'd have to say this is probably at least my second favorite album of theirs.  Anyone who is a Paramore fan should definitely buy this album.
Takes a little getting used to their new sound... not bad, just different. Hayley still sounds amazing!
A genuinely great rock album. Their best in my opinion. Her voice amazes me at times.....many times on this album. Taylor is a serious guitarist too.

'don't judge a book by the cover' comes to mind with this CD and band:) when I saw the band I thought they might be a punk band or something hard core not what I'm into at all. But I fell for "Ain't it Fun" and just felt I had to get the MP3 of the whole album (yah I'm that girl that will buy a whole CD because she likes one song so sue me:P) and after listening to the whole album I love the band and the MP3:) they have a great sound and the lead singer's voice is amazing:) great band and CD:)

This is GREAT!!!!!!!!!  I LOVE EVERY SONG!!!!!!!  I think this young lady has so much talent.  She brings every song to life with expression & feeling.  She is amazing.  My favorite is Grow Up.  I love the part of the song that She tells her friends they can stick it!!!!!!!!  The clarity in her voice is very expressive.  Actually, all of the songs are fun and up beat.  I love them all.  I am so glad I decided to buy this & I recommend it to everyone that loves a good beat and easy to listen to lyrics.  Fun music!!!!!!!!

Paramore seems to be heading into some new territory and it might take some getting used to for me... "Brand New Eyes" had me spoiled, I think, and while bands should always be seeking to set the bar ever higher and create fresh new sounds, I'm not sure if that's what this self-titled LP is... YET. The most addictive track I find, is probably the most experimental for Paramore, "Ain't It Fun." Sounds like something MJ would have done in his prime. It will be interesting to see what singles will be released and what singles garner airplay.

If we are "choosing sides" about two of the original band members leaving vs Hayley's feelings about it, I'm on their side if what they said went down the way it did. However, if we're talking about music that expresses how someone gets over being hurt, no matter who's right or wrong, Hayley with the rest of the band turned out an amazing 17 track album. So diverse I didn't know what to think at first, but then, track by track, they all blew me away. Long time and new fans alike, buy this album!

review_title: Different, but still great to listen to
review_text: I love Paramore and while this album sounds different from the previous three, I am loving the new sound.  There are a number of Interludes that have an old fashioned sound to them.  Personally, I like them, but not everyone will.  My dad found it helpful to just not include those tracks when he put this on his phone.  The album has great lyrics and great music and I appreciate that Paramore always gives us something new.

It's been almost 4 years since the last Paramore studio album. It's worth the wait. This album is different compared to the previous albums. And this album has several different moods and style. It makes it very fun to listen to. There aren't any hard rock songs like Crushcrushcrush or Emergency. But, it's still a great Paramore album. Don't be fooled by the long list of songs. There are 14 songs just like any other normal studio album, but there are three interludes. Many of the songs are at least 4 star songs. It's really worth buying the whole album instead of individual songs, wether you're a fan or not. I'd rank this CD higher than Brand New Eyes. It knocks that album out of the park and puts it to shame.

Bought this when it first came out, but its taken me a while to get into it. Its a much more mature sound and music than from the days of Riot, but in a good way. While I'm a big fan of their older style, I'll admit that this was a well executed foray into different musical styles.One of the few albums I can listen to this album backwards and forwards.This is now my favorite Paramore album.
Came on black vinyl with white spread through it, inverse to what was promised. I am returning it to get a different color because it just looks perpetually dusty. Three stars for being a good album
Love the whole album. Very upbeat and then slows down a bit. This is my first experience purchasing an entire album from this band. Not disappointed.

Since most people have already reviewed the music itself on this thread, I chose to describe the Vinyl packaging itself in this review.  This album is spread over two regular weight vinyl LPs.  Would have liked to see them be pressed on 180 gram vinyl, but oh well.  The vinyl color is black, and the center labels are different colors for each side. This is NOT a gatefold album, and both LPs are housed in the main opening.  It does include a colorful lyric sheet, but does NOT include a high quality download of the album (although the AutoRip from Amazon function takes care of that!).  The sound quality on the vinyls is excellent.  Couldn't hear any distortion and/or glitches with the audio quality at all.  If anything, it sounds even richer and more enhanced than its CD/MP3 counterparts.  Overall, I was very happy with the double vinyl set and feel like it is worth a purchase!

review_title: Good Album!  Decent ratio of good songs to "meh" songs...worth buying the whole disc
review_text: Really like this album.  Never much listened to Paramore in the past, but like this one.I always buy the CD's and rip them with lossless compression to get better sound quality than the normal lossy MP3 compression you get from Amazon or Itunes.Plus, if you buy the CD you get the free MP3's from Amazon music anyway for when you really don't need the extra sound quality or don't have it locally on your device.
Didn’t think I was gonna like the album until I bought the cassette and it was I wrong. Plays well in my truck and looks cool! Worth the buy if you like Paramore

review_title: I don't even like Paramore, but I love this album
review_text: I don't even like Paramore, but I love this album. I'm not sure if that's a good thing for Paramore fans or not!
Love Paramore and love their new sound! The new album is really good. There's a few songs I don't care for, but overall it's a good album.

It came really fast with the prime shipping and the packaging was alright. I love this album, but, my heart broke when I saw a sharp dent on Side B. Now the song gets stuck on that one dent. I'm not sure if I can still return/exchange because I already played the record (well, was hoping the dent wouldn't affect how the songs play...). Please let me know if I can exchange!!! Or if there's anyway I can fix the sharp dent please please please let me know as well!!!!

review_title: If At First You Dont Like It , Listen again!
review_text: This album at first I wasn't sure about but it has grown on me over time. I feel this is a really solid effort from the band and while I dont necessarily want them to go back to the Pop Punk style I would like to hear more rock influence in their next record. I felt the Self Titled album held a perfect balance of everything.

review_title: Great album. Paramore is one of those bands that ...
review_text: Great album. Paramore is one of those bands that changes with every album, and I'm always excited to hear their new sound.  The sound is most similar to the self titled era, but definitely has a new individual sound to it. I would highly recommend this album for any fan of Paramore's music!

I can see why some Paramore fans don't care as much for this album.  There are previous ones that I like better myself, but I think there is still a solid album here.  Actually a couple of my favorite songs are on this album.  One of the things I have always like about this band is that their music, while sometimes sounding familiar, always seems fresh and different and they continue to deliver with this album.

I love this album, I love the band, and I love the style change, though my opinion may be biased to be truthful. I probably would have ignored half of all Paramore songs if I had discovered Paramore after the release of this self-titled album because I would have thought of them to be either cliché, too optimistic/positive, too corny, too 'not-exactly-my-style', or all of the above. I have loved Paramore, and their past and present band members, for many, many years now, and not just for their talent, but also for their genuine acts and words towards their fans and their meaningful music, so the positivity and uniqueness of this album could not (and will not) draw me away. Whether the songs of the album seem to be cliché and corny, or not, all of the songs as a whole still have this one important purpose: to make listeners happy. In my opinion, the mission has been accomplished.The album is well worth the money. It includes seventeen songs, three of them being interludes, and my purchase came with a digital version of the album to my Amazon cloud, which I am so very grateful for.Was this honest review helpful?

Despite being somewhat of a departure from previous works in style, this album is great music.  Many of the songs become genuinely addictive after a few listens.  Lyrically, the songs are easy to identify with while keeping emotions close to the surface.
This album hits home lyrically for me... probably my favorite Paramore album overall. I love the marble vinyl, it’s very cool looking. Great for the collection.

review_title: Been a Paramore fan since i was 12 back in 2007 RIOT era
review_text: I just wanna thank God and Beyoncé (she had nothing to do with the album but you gotta always stay gracious 🙏) This is the first Paramore vinyl, the fist limited edition vinyl, and the first Paramore limited edition vinyl that I've bought. It's like they always know what stage in my life I am and what I'm into and they make and album out of it. This album is amazing with this whole retro wave sound. Love how Paramore always knows what's up and are always evolving musically no matter the challenges they face our them and within them.
Recieved my record, but got a standard black record, not the marbled one.

review_title: Great cd! Paramore is my favorite band
review_text: Great cd! Paramore is my favorite band! I was curious how this album would be since they lost two of their original members but it does not disappoint! It is a different sound from the previous albums but it is still amazing!! Some of my favorite songs from them are in this album!!

review_title: After all the time, I'm still into it...
review_text: With 17 tracks to listen to, it's a lot to pick and choose your favorites. It's definitely more poppy  than the previous albums maybe because they are using different sounds and such and the rock edge is get smoothed over but it is still great songwriting that is unmistakeably Paramore. It's hard to dislike anything Haley sings. She has a great voice and lyrics. Instrumentation and arrangements serve each song well.
Great upbeat music! I did listen to it on Youtube first before deciding to buy the whole album.

I've been a Paramore fan for years, and despite losing two members, I think this is the best Paramore's ever been. There's been so much growth since Brand New Eyes and the album itself satisfies so many different musical genres. I really love the interludes, and almost every single song on the album is one of those songs you wouldn't be afraid to blast for the world to hear.I especially love Part II because I really feel like it's the perfect sequel to past songs, hence the name, but it's definitely one of my favorites. All of the songs have really great, relate-able lyrics as well, so I really commend the band for such great works.I'm sad to see so many that do not appreciate such an amazing change. Don't get me wrong, I own and love their other albums too, but I feel like things can only get better from here.
It wasn’t actually marbled but has faint white splotches on the vinyl. Either way, the music will be good and the sound is excellent with no scratches.
Got the white marble and its beautiful!

So great. It took me a while, but it grew on me. Hayley sure does show all her colors in this album and I think it really revamps the Paramore group as a whole now that there are new members. But the awesomeness doesn't die.

review_title: Very different. A little confusing at first. Not ...
review_text: Very different. A little confusing at first.Not a lot of power. Still, it's very catchy and grows on you.

review_title: Not bent! Perfect shape and sounds great!
review_text: Record came in really great packaging and was not damaged in any way. Super happy with this purchase!
Great album and super cool vinyl records. You can't beat the price and it's Paramore... doesn't get better than that!

Paramore has come along and their self-titled album appears to be appropriately named.  The entire album from track one to sixteen is utmost power driven pop music that bears many comparisons that continue to go through this listener’s head even at the last spin of the final track.  From the grunge to dance pop sounds that resonate with much of the sound of the 1980s and 1990s, the album is sure to please.  Paramore and producers Justin Meldel-Johnson and Ilan Rubin played an enormous part to the sounds heard on the record that echo much with Brian Eno and Nile Rodgers.Imagine growing up in the 1980s and hearing the opening drum rolls of any fast-paced Blondie song such as “Dreaming” and the pounding done by Clem Burke, “Day Dreaming” and “Fast in My Car” have that sound.  Also, one wonders was the band listening to early U2 or Echo and the Bunnymen for the atmospheric “Part II.”  Most of the songs on the album contain keyboards and synthesizers and that big production sound of the 80’s but not so much bordering on Cyndi Lauper’s “Girls Just Want to Have Fun,” but “Grow Up” comes close.  Within the same lines of Lauper, Hayley Williams adds a bit ukele a la Rudy Vallee with “Interlude Moving On” “Interlude Holiday,”  “Interlude I’m Not Angry Anymore.”  And the singles are quite enticing to listen to “Still into You” and “Ain’t it Fun,” which is reminiscent of the funk and pop of Teen Marie with its very danceable beat and unforgettable lyrics.  “Be Alone” is the most power pop song on the record and “Proof” and “Future” has grunge-Seattle style written all over each one.The band has produced a very eclectic album that may appeal to every listener that is interested in wanting to know the sound that is Paramore.  This is the album that unveils the infectious vocals of Hayley Williams and the musicianship of Jeremy Davis and Taylor York and that Paramore sound.

review_title: This was a gift for my son he absolutely love Paramore he was not disappointed when he received his ...
review_text: This was a gift for my son he absolutely love Paramore he was not disappointed when he received his gift if you're a Paramore fan then you would love this album too

I can't get enough of this album. My only warning is that it does not come with the 2 bonus tracks, but those can be purchased and  downloaded elsewhere. I love how the band is growing and changing their sound. This is one of those albums that you need to listen through the whole tracklist in order to catch all the brilliance of the album.

Paramore is bass heavy... and that's what I like. The lead singer, Hayley Williams is an energetic firecracker with an awesome voice!The songs vary from super popish to laid back and fun. A lot of it seems like reflections of an angsty teenager embarking on a new decade though. So, if youre not appreciative of a maturing teen then this album isn't for you.Hayleys got a great voice, sounding a lot like a cross between Gwen stephani and Belinda Carlisle with the attitude of joan Jett. I rate this 4 stars because its not what I expected from a Paramore album, but still worth the buy.

LOVE THIS ALBUM! Every song on here is amazing, and the pressing is great. The jacket is basically damage proof, and it comes with two inner sleeves. I only wish I got a different colored pressing, but the black marble is great!

review_title: A fantastic album from an extremely talented band
review_text: Great album from a super talented band with a unique sound and a killer lead singer!The CD arrived in perfect condition in it's case, no scratches, factory sealed, etc. Amazon comes through as always.The actual album absolutely rules. This is the first full Paramore album I've bought, so I was unaware that they had a strong punk-pop vibe beyond the more unique, kickass sound of their singles. They're a "Fueled by Ramen" Artist and absolutely can hang with anyone else in that label there. So if you like that kind of stuff, you'll like every song here, because that's what the WORST they do sounds like. The best they can do? Well, you've heard the singles off the album by now hopefully. It not, go listen to, "Ain't it Fun" or "Still Into You" a.s.a.p. There's also songs like "Anklebiters" and "Daydreaming" here that are fantastic in the same vein. And some stuff that's fantastic but show a little bit of a different side, like "(One of those) Crazy Girls" with it's more playful melody or the slower jam sounds of "Hate to See Your Heart Break". They hit a lot of bases on this album and pretty much everything sounds great.Even the interludes are really neat. The completely chill sound of "I'm not angry anymore" with it's ukulele is awesome in its own, unique way.Absolutely recommended. This band is killer and their self-titled CD doesn't disappoint.
I really like the design of the disc itself. The entire thing is black, but the album name is glossy rather than matte. Subtle and beautiful.

review_title: A little bit softer than the past but still great
review_text: Its not as loud as some of their previous work, but its also not as poppy. It took a bit of an indy role, but not entirely. Its an album that you can listen to all day and relax. Honestly, I kind feel like if you were to play only the music and remove the vocals of haley williams, i dont think anyone would be able to tell that this was paramore. I am still a fan of this album though. Haley is the bomb...

Tape is great, tape was brand spanking new and worked fine, although i am surprised that it was intact with the packaging they had for it. The tape must've been flying all over the box so I'm lucky it didn't break.

review_title: Hit me right in the feels.
review_text: Hit me right in the feels. Maybe because I was in the same state of mind. Who knows.

review_title: If you're a collector be aware.
review_text: I have an issue with the shipping. There was inadequate protection allowing the jewel case to crack.

review_title: Vinyl version lives up to expectations
review_text: I've been a fan of paramore for a while but this is the first vinyl I've bought because I thought the style of music on this album would sound best, AND IT DOES! The funk pop punk really shines in vinyl form. On top of it I actually got the while marble one so I was pleasantly surprised.

review_title: It's an amazing record. Paramore uses a new sound and Hayley ...
review_text: It's an amazing record. Paramore uses a new sound and Hayley experiments with a new singing styles. The lyrics are great and you can feel the dedication they put into this album.
Love hayley williams so much. Every time a new album comes out, they have a new interesting sound! I'm such a fan!!
Beautiful album visually and musically.  Have been listening to it on repeat!
the record itself wasn’t bad, got a little scratch on it after a play or two. i love this album to bits, it’s my favorite by paramore.

review_title: Lots of change...and change is good.
review_text: Paramore is a band that I have been following since they made their mark on the music world around 2007-2008 and I have been eagerly anticipating the 4th self-titled album. I knew that there was a lot of change coming especially since this band has gone from a quintet to a three man band. Basically, this is not like the past three albums and where this band is going is still a bit of a mystery. There are a lot of different sounds represented in this album. From new wave, pop and indi (featured in the interludes) Haley Williams has definitely come a long way. Her high volume blasts have turned into very mellow and soulful ones and she has become quite dynamic by setting all the different tones for each song. No two songs are quite the same in this record and that makes each one a good listen. I would have to say my favorite song on this album would probably be 'Daydreaming' like most songs I enjoy this one just has one of those hookey choruses that I love.Like all the bands I enjoy listening to, I always enjoy something fresh and new. Still, it always leaves me wondering what will be coming down in the line the future. So far based on what Paramore gave me this time around, I am ready to see what I will get.

This is a great album. Paramore never ceases to amaze me with each of their albums, and this one in particular is very catchy. If you're into punk rock, check them out. They're really good at what they do with their music.In my honest opinion, this is the best album I have heard from them so far.
GREAT APBUM!!!!! EVEN GREATER IF YOU ARE A COLLECTOR. CASSETTE TAPES RULE!!!!!

This is an all around great CD! I purchased it after hearing "Still Into You" on the radio and was pleasantly surprised to find that the whole CD is full of great music! The lead singer, Hayley Williams, is a gifted singer that pours everything she has into ever track on the disc. I am glad that Paramore is getting some much deserved air time on a national level and will be buying more of their  music in the near future.
The marbled vinyl looks so cool and of course the music is fantastic. You can't go wrong with Paramore.

I was debating on whether to purchasing the world Paramore album or not, but eventually i did purchased it. It still has the old Paramore vibe for what they are known for. i enjoy listening it the entire album and each song is different with its beat, and rhythm.
Great album great band, l love the fact I get a digital copy with it. Amazon rocks!

This album felt more like a demo or a collection of songs that were quickly thrown together. It doesn't seem like they have regained their meld of being a band and could have tightened up the set list a bit before releasing this album. There are a few stand out tracks, but the album feels like a person rambling on without a lot of direction.

review_title: It's pretty optimistic for a pessimistic band...
review_text: This album has more synthiness than their "old" stuff.  If that bothers you, then I really must question why you even listen to music...unless you're a cantankerous 65 year old who needs their music to have some sliver of resemblance to whatever you considered "hip" back in 1970...I'm 32 and I like this CD.  The genre of this album is the same as RIOT!, this is not bubblegum pop any more so than RIOT! was.  That being said, it is a much better album.  It's so good I have a hard time getting to enjoy the whole thing.  I get track 4 and I'm so pumped up I need to take a break.  It's got more life to it than their older stuff.  It's not as negative, but it still has a hint of melancholy throughout, some songs more than others...It's very melodic, Hayley Williams voice shines like always and the guitars are not missing.  I would imagine Paramore hires a touring guitarist since it does sound like either two guitarists playing or multiple layers of guitar, on a lot of the album.  This album benefits from more open-ness in the production.  I go back and listen to "For A Pessimist I'm Pretty Optimistic" and the music sounds like a scratched up vinyl record.  And then the second track on RIOT!, "That's What You Get", just sounds shallow.  And when I say "sounds", I'm not referring to the "heart and soul" of the song, I'm just referring to the sound itself.  (People should quit saying things they don't mean and leaving others' to "use common sense" as a means to put words in other people's mouths.)

I was apprehensive of this cd when Zac and Josh left. And a lot of the songs on it do lean in the the more "pop" direction. It's not the same Paramore that we are used to, but it is still amazing. I am still unwavering a hardcore Paramore fan. A lot of the songs on this cd you hear more from the guys singing and I absolutely loved that.

review_title: This album appeals to a wide audience
review_text: I downloaded this Album at the 2013 Z100 Jingle Ball concert right after Paramore's set. I couldn't get enough! The singer has an amazing voice and puts on a great performance. I am an R&B fan but also enjoy alternative, punk, etc. I love the fusion of punk/R&B/Pop in this album. I am going to go and download their previous albums now! Oh, and I am DEFINITELY playing "Still into You" for my 10th wedding anniversary next year!

I've been a huge fan of this band since their first album release. I have loved every single song they put out, so of course, I was excited about their new album. I pre-ordered it and got day of shipping. It arrived just on time, perfect condition. I put it in and listened and was SO AMAZED by the variety of sound on this CD. Paramore was clearly exploring, because no song on this album (with the exception of the interludes) sound the same. From "Fast in my Car" all the way to "Future", this album gives you a great new Paramore. I can't wait to see what they do next. They never fail to disappoint!

I've been a fan of Paramore since the start and I absolutely love this album. For those who say they miss Paramore's old sound I must say I disagree. I'll admit that I was a bit unsure at first because their sound has definitely changed- but for the better! This album is a great mix of different genres along with interludes that mold every track together. I can feel that they've grown as friends, band mates, musicians and people the more I listen to this album. Paramore is no longer the angst filled teens we fell in love with,but now a mature and less angsty adults who are making great music for everyone to enjoy. After all, "some of us have to grow up sometime."
Amazing, and I got the sweet white marble edition.
Anything Paramore is amazing!!
Bought as Christmas gift
Bought as Christmas gift

Paramore is always great putting lots of songs into an album and making them all flow well to the next. Hayley Williams make you fall for her over and over again. you guys won't be disappointed with the song choices its got great songs for both guys and girls. You'll love it!

This album is great, although their sound has changed a bit since the departure of the Farro brothers they still are producing a great sound. Aint it fun is an up tempo song but I adore Part II (part 2 to Let the Flames begin from the Riot album) and Crazy girls is fun and lighthearted. A little bit of hard and soft on this album but I have no complaints. I can't wait to see Paramore in concert in my town this summer (2014) with Fall Out Boy, its going to be a RIOT!!

I was looking forward to getting the CD in mp3 format but since it came free with the actual CD it was a real deal. It took a couple listens all the way through to really get into the new sound but I'm definitely happy with it. Looking forward to seeing them in concert this month in Atlanta!

It's has more of a retro sound to it. LOVE IT! I do miss the 'rocky" edge the previous records had though. This album is different from the old Paramore, but you have to look at the fact that there are new members and bands have to evolve to stay afloat, even if it means disappointing old Paramore lovers. I think the next album will be right on key.

I was a little sceptical at first. I loved Paramore's first three albums and I wasn't sure I was going to like their new stuff especially after I heard their first single. However without knowing I was one, I proved myself to be a die-hard Paramore fan. Not only do I LOVE this album. It is, in my opinion, their best record yet. It's personal its raw and its got such honesty. All three musicians shine and I could not be happier. Money well spent. I bought it two more times for friends birthdays. They loved it too!

I was disappointed with this cd. I had seen her live in concert, her music was more on the punk/heavy alternative side. The cd is more of a pop song collection. There was one song at the end that was heavy. I had wished the whole cd was like that. I gave it to my niece.

review_title: Good Paramore Album, but not as good
review_text: I have all of their previous albums. But when I listened to this one, I was torn. It sounds like a great album. Great mix of songs, nice flow throughout. But it just didn't sound like a Paramore album. Whether this had to do with the loss of the Farro brothers, or another outside force. But it just didn't have the same power to it.

This isn't their best work, but I do like the new album. A lot of different styles are represented here, showing their talent -- especially Haley's vocals. Just don't expect some of the same grit and gut from their past albums. This is definitely more poppy, radio-friendly.

This direction for Paramore is absolutely dynamic!  The band digs deep into the 80's & 90's alternative pop sounds to produce a variegated energized set of songs!  Recalling the ethereality of Harriet Wheeler's (of The Sundays) lilting vocals to the poignant punk/ska blend of No Doubt, Hayley Williams transcends the pop genre with subtle stylings full of energy, vibrancy, emotion, and virtuosity!  Truly a band that has much more in store for the future!!

I really like the addition of the sutble electronic elements, and some of the songs have a more raw sound mixed with these very modern elements which really pop.I would recommend this album to anyone who is a fan of Paramore, I don't think you'll be disappointed.My favorite tracks on the album so far:Fast In My CarNowDaydreamingPart IILast HopeAnd as a bonus, I really like the ukulele interludes.

After reading some of the initial reviews, I felt like this EP was getting an unfair shake. The reviews suggested that the CD is all over the place, not truly committing to a theme, or following a formula. To those reviewers, I ask, does it have to follow a theme? Is this an opus, or just merely a collection of good songs? I choose the latter.Highlights for me are the 80s rooted "Ain't It Fun," and the call to action of "Grow Up," both with soaring, infectious hooks that really put the magic that Ms. Williams vocals are known for on display. The interludes are fun and playful, and the rest of the tracks are all hits in their own right. Solid effort!

review_title: They tried some new stuff, it worked for me
review_text: Hayley did some great things with her voice on this album and the band branched out into a couple of different musical styles.  A lot of the album had a really nice '80s pop/rock and roll feel to it, and I loved it for that.  I especially appreciated that it was, for the most part, more upbeat than I was expecting it to be.  It's been in my playlist a lot and I like this as much as any Paramore album if only because they didn't descend into too much moperock.  That kind of stuff appeals to kids, but so much of this album is about maturity, growing up and letting go of pasts that anchor you down that when you think about it, freed from yesterday's chains, one should have the spirit to soar.  It's not what I expected, and I loved it for that, too.  Hayley's vocals really showed off a lot more range on this album, and that was probably the most refreshing thing about it.

review_title: A definite hit, but not your mother’s Paramore
review_text: If there was any question of Paramore’s transition from pop-rock to straight-up pop after the release of 2013’s Self Titled album, After Laughter is the answer.  Hayley’s metamorphosis from an angsty rock goddess to a somehow-even-more angsty pop princess is all but complete.  Those of us that fell in love with the pop-rock Paramore sound from the “All We Know Is Falling” through “Brand New Eyes” era may be disappointed to find a near-total lack of crunchy guitar and head-banging riffs, instead replaced with a collection of catchy earworms reminiscent at times of a popular pop tunes of the 80s.  But is this a bad thing?  That’s a decision best left to the listener.  This sound certainly has a wider appeal, if not alienating some of fans that have been around since the beginning.  Some reviewers call the change in the band’s sound an “evolution”, but I disagree – to me, evolution implies improvement, but the sound is almost so different that it’s impossible to compare to the first three albums.  It’s simply too much of a change.All that said, After Laughter is a fantastic album.  “Hard Times” does a wonderful job of setting the tone with a poppy upbeat sound paired with lyrics that seem to convey the exact opposite.  This premise bleeds into other tracks (“Told You So”, “Fake Happy”, etc.) to the point that it’s a recurring theme of the album.  And while the general sound throughout After Laughter is very much pop, it has a much more classic pop feel, ranging from 80s popular hits to 90s adult contemporary.  The product is an album that is just plain fun to listen to.  I was also happy to hear another experimental track (“No Friend”) continuing the trend from the Self Titled album.So after admitting that After Laughter is a fantastic album, why have I only given it 3 stars?  Personally, I miss the Paramore of old.  If you liked Self Titled, there’s a good chance you’ll love After Laughter.  I’d prefer to see Paramore return to their roots, but I readily admit this album is an artistic achievement and am confident it will be a huge hit.  I’m holding out hope we can get some heavier tracks on the next album, but in the meantime After Laughter will be in my rotation.And as before, I still love you Hayley ;)

review_title: Paramore is back, Happy, with a few twists.
review_text: Okay, so first off, I do not do reviews. I have been an amazon customer for over two years, placing orders on nearly a bi-weekly basis and this is my first review. I just felt that this album deserved it. This album is different from what we expect from Paramore but that is to be expected. With all they have gone through change is due, with losing the Farro Brothers, I'm surprised they managed to remain as true as they did to what we are used to.In this album, we hear a much more optimistic band. With nearly four years since their last album, this album shows paramore taking risks, and emerging from their comfort zone. They are developing their range, and quite frankly I think that's amazing. In this album, many people suggest that the band is more "pop", but I don't think these people have listened to the full album. There are some songs up here that are unique to say the least, but you can hear the old paramore we all fell in love with throughout the album. The highlights of this album are Part II, which incorporates lyrics from "Let the flames begin" from Riot. This is too awesome to me being able to hear those lyrics revived and relived. Last hope takes us back to the softer paramore, such as the only exception, breath, and many songs from the first album. There are a few other slow songs up here as well, like future and hate to see your heart break. While slow, they show the purity of Hayley's voice. Other highlights include Still into you, and despite having a pop like verse, the chorus takes us back to that alternative band. You find that a lot in this album, verses incorporate things that are totally different from what we are used to, but the choruses often times stay the same, which we see in Still into you, now, Proof, and Ani't it fun. This album shows a funner paramore, in songs like crazy girls, and fast in my car.While it is true they have matured, we see in this album a reborn Paramore. This album is by no means as great as All we know is falling, which in my opinion was their greatest work, but it is still an album that magnifys one of the greatest bands ever. Haley shows us a different side of her, and in the lyrics, we see a band that is so incredibly happy, and optimistic. It is different, and many scruitenize this album because of that, but once you listen to the entire album once, your hooked. You hear the old paramore still in there, alongside a new paramore that is just trying to show how much they have grown in the past four years. Wonderful album, I have listed to it cover to over about eight times, which translates into about nine hours in two days. It is well worth it, and with 17 tracks, you can't go wrong. One note is there are two bonus tracks, which are not included on the physical album but can be listened to on rido for free. These are escape route, which is the old Paramore one hundred percent. I highly recommend you listen to this, because this is by far the best song for this album, and seems like many of the songs on the third album. The other bonus track is "native tongue" which is decent, but not the cream of the crop.All in all this album does not disappoint. The cream of the crop lays in Last hope (my personal favorite), Part II, Ain't it fun, crazy girls, proof and the best is escape route, but unfourtantly it's not on the physical album

review_title: Buy this NOW if you want to be happy
review_text: SO GOOD!  I seriously love this album.  I've loved Paramore from the beginning and it's always scary when one of your favorite bands changes/loses band members but this album far surpasses my expectations.  It's a bit more poppy than their previous albums - it's more fun and catchy - less guitar driven but that's NOT a bad thing!  (I detest a lot of pop music don't get me wrong) I love their old stuff and I love this new stuff!  I honestly don't get how there can be bad reviews about this album...those people must just hate the world.  The lyrics are still great and every song is unique.There's a little bit of everything on this album and it's one of the few albums I've bought that I thoroughly LOVED the first time I listened to it.  A lot of times I have to give a new CD (yes I still buy CDs) a few listens before I judge it.  I haven't been so excited about how good a CD is in a long time.Thank you Paramore for staying awesome!  Please stay around a LONG time and give us lots more music greatness!  EVERYONE ELSE - buy this now so they have a reason to!

review_title: This is my first paramore album purchase.
review_text: This is my first paramore album purchase. I've heard the singles of her other albums over the years and some I enjoyed and others were ok. I remember a girlfriend years back listening to riot and i was like man, this is mad girl music. I can say that hayley has matured and that this album has a concise theme that touches on subjects that I especially can relate too. Feeling like you have to live up to certain expectations, failure, being scared etc. Everyone can relate to these issues and its refreshing to hear her talk about how she feels. A lot of people think that celebrities or people who are super successful have no problems, but they are people just like us.This album has a very summer feel to it. There are songs that have really good production on this album.Some stand out tracks to me areHard TimesTold you soFake happy26 - changes up the pace, acoustic, real nice song.pool - summer beatidle worship - shows emotion in trying to not disappoint but having to accept that she has to be who she is.Rose-Colored boy has this chant that is catchy: "Low-key, no pressure, just hang with me and my weather". Reminds me of the Ting Tings not my name.Caught in the middle has a nice guitar riff.I have only heard the entire album 2 times through and through. I dont think there is a skippable track in this album, it goes by real fast.So basically after saying all of that, as a male, yes this has some feminine tones in it, yes its not the same sad girl music from years back but I feel that this is an honest expression of self and a great record to add to your collection.

Obvious differences due to band changes, new experimentation with different sounds, and the melodies and vocals are still strong. But it's so obvious that something is "missing" compared to previous works.In my opinion, this album is lighter and "thinner" than previous albums. I'd like to hear some different arrangements on some of these pieces to see if they can be improved a bit for a more memorable experience.Nothing real eye catching on this album, but overall, still fun and a good listen. I'm not seeing adding this album among my favorites, though.

review_title: Yet another Paramore that fails to disappoint me.
review_text: The minute that I saw that this was out, I ordered it on Amazon Prime before evening listening to any besides "Hard Times" and "Told you So", so I had a small taste of what to expect. When I first listened to it in my car, I was having a great time just without paying too much attention to lyrics or what the songs were called or anything and thought it was pretty good. The more I listen to it, the more I like it. The only song I don't really get into is "No Friend" since IMP they should have the lyrics much more clear so they're much more distinguishable. It's one of those songs that really stands out from the rest; the lyrics, the overall mood of it, and especially that it's not Hayley singing it. It's not that I don't like it, it has some pretty deep lyrics that I'm pretty sure it references a bunch of past Paramore lyrics too.  There are many track on here I find very favorable; Fake Happy, Idle Worship, Pool, Hard Times, Rose-Colored Boy, and Told you So. The rest I also love listening to as well over and over again. They each have their own charm, like the relatable lyrics of "Fake Happy" "..Oh Please! Just don't ask me how I've been. Don't make me play pretend. Oh no! Oh, what's the use? Oh please! I bet everybody here is fake happy too" or "Just let me let you downHey, baby I'm not your superhumanAnd if that's what you wantI hate to let you downI got your hopes upNow I got you hopingBut I'm gonna be the one that let you down" from "Idle Worship" I don't know which album of Paramore is my favorite out of "All we know is falling", "Riot!", "Brand New Eyes", "Paramore" and now this one. I'm loving this one and am wondering what their next album will sound like when it most likely comes out 2021. Some people may not like that they aren't going back to the kind of sound and energy that is heard from "Riot!" but either way, the most important thing is it's the music the makes the band members satisfied with their work. There are going to be haters whether the music goes towards a new direction or stays about the same so they might as well goes with what feels right, and this music definitely feels right to my ears. If you don't like it, that's fine, just accept that, just like a person, it's going to change over time. Thank you for your time.

review_title: So, I thought to myself, it can't really be THAT bad...
review_text: Yes. I saw the bad reviews, but at 3.99, I thought "what the hell, it can't be all that bad, can it?"What we have here is a huge shift for Paramore. On the great cosmic Rock-Pop scale of female fronted bands, with The Distillers and L7 at one end and Olivia Newton-John and Justin Bieber at the other, Paramore has slid from somewhere around Joan Jett, blowing right past Evanescence, to end up somewhere just north of Katy Perry.I guess it's really not that bad of an album, if you like that sort of music, which I don't really, then go for it. (And perhaps consider therapy of some sort.)

review_text: I like it but it's not Paramore.  Paramore was always about great guitar riffs matched with equally great melodies and vocals.  There isn't a single track that has a prominent guitar riff on it, and definitely no distortion.  This album is really good, but it's not Paramore, it should've just been a side-project of Hayley's - or another Chvrches album.

There were a couple standout songs, and a few that I don't mind, but unfortunately I'd describe half of this album as boring. review_title: Short album of upbeat pop that is ultimiately rather forgettable.
review_text: A short, refreshingly upbeat album that is strongly pop-focused but fails to be memorable. A nice exploration into a modern pop sound infused with ventures into distinct decades of musical influence. Fans of early Paramore might not find much to like in this album, as the rock back end that helped Paramore diversify in a crowded market is only loosely present. "Fake Happy" and "Caught in the Middle" are the closest reminders of songs from Riot! or Brand New Eyes, but would nonetheless feel out of place in comparison. And yet, opening tracks "Hard Times" and "Rose-Colored Boy" show a creative genius in their use of recognizable 70's and 80's hooks for a modern pop fusion, though they are ultimately as forgettable as the rest. While 2013's self-titled album had hits and misses, it did show a growth and depth that is sadly lacking in After Laughter.Overall, Paramore's latest album has the same beautiful, strong vocals but lacks any semblance of risk. It is an album that feels safe and comfortable. An enjoyable listen but not up to par with any of their other albums to date. Yet another band member lineup adjustment makes a distinct sound difference, and the only thing that remains consistent is Hayley's William's vocals.

I must admit that for the longest time, i truly despised Paramore. For no particular reason (except maybe their fans, but that's a stupid reason to dislike something). Finally, I listened to Riot! and was hooked instantly (truly shocking because my fave bands are Marilyn Manson, NIN, Ministry, ect). Around that time I started reading all the articles about how Hayley Williams split with the original dudes and was making a dramatic return. I thought that Paramore was probably over before I could even fully get into them.... Skip forward a couple months to the release of the single "Now", and i downloaded it cuz...well, it's only a dollar right? I put it onto a random playlist and was blown away by how good it was--almost instantly! Later that night i ordered the album. It was extra tantalizing waiting for the record to arrive, because it took weeks longer than the seller had informed me (that's what i get for going the cheaper route). It was gonna have to be a damn good record for how long i waited for it. Finally, i lost all interest in hearing it as I decided to listen to Riot! on my walk home one warm spring day. It was a semi-rough day, so it felt nice to chill out and listen to it all the way home at a nice, leisurely pace. I got home, and to my amazement, a small brown package laid waiting in my mailbox! This particular album had become something of a ridiculous myth in my mind, so I was slightly hesitant to actually listen to it. I decided to eat some dinner first. The wait eventually became waaaaayyyy too brutal so i put it on while making dinner...WOW. I was astonished by how much i liked it upon first listen! I usually need to warm up to new CDs (even ones that are now my very favorites), so this came as quite a surprise. In fact, EVERY song was 10/10, even the "Interludes", which I usually don't like on most records. In short, if you like Paramore, you'll LOVE this album. If you like solid, well-written rock music with infectious hooks, you'll LOVE this album. If you don't know how you feel about them, this is a great one to start with. Another prime example of why 2013 is shaping up to be one of the greatest years in music I've ever experienced. Not to be missed!

Despite losing key songwriters the band was able to put together a great set of interesting and fun songs.  It's not all classic pop-punk, but departures are often the best songs like the funkier "Ain't It Fun".  "Daydreaming" has an undercurrent of Blondie's "Dreaming" to it and the run between it and "Part II" is my favorite section of the album.  But right after that you get two classic Paramore style songs in "Last Hope" and "Still Into You".It's less "consistent" than Brand New Eyes but it might be more entertaining in the long run.  Either way, it fits the catalog very well and makes me glad they stuck with it.

review_title: If you loved the previous Paramore album, you'll be delighted by this
review_text: Paramore has been through so many line-up changes in their history, I've lost track of all the comings and goings. This latest line-up sees the departure of bassist Jeremy David and the return of original drummer Zac Farro. But of course there is one constant in all of this, and that is singer/front woman Hayley Williams."After Laughter" (12 tracks; 43 min.) is Paramore's 5th studio album, and once again Williams and Co. deliver the goods, churning out anthem after anthem. The album opens with "Hard Times" (1st single), my favorite track of the album. But the highlights are many. Despite the line-up changes, the album sounds surprisingly cohesive. Other highlights include the high energy "Told You So", the acoustic "26", the rocking "Grudges", and towards the very end, the infectious "No Friend". At just over 40 min., this album flies by in no time.I had the good fortune of seeing Paramore in concert at the 2014 Bunbury Music Festival here in Cincinnati, when the band was touring in support of the previous (self-titled) album and its monster hit "Ain't It Fun". What a great set that was, and the massive audience absolutely loved it. I can only hope they will come back to Cincinnati soon! Meanwhile, "After Laughter" is a very satisfactory return of William & Co.

Paramore can perform, and put on a show, she has tons of energy and a voice I have fallen in love since day I heard her. I understand the band was trying to show another side of them, I honestly think they should stick to their old style if they want to keep the name PARAMORE. The reason I started to listen to Paramore in the first place was that hard sounding not-so-mainstream rock music where Haley's passionate, powerful, perfectly pitched and extremely flexible, angelical voice that was sent into battle armed with a set of heavy drums, hot-picking power chord distorted guitar. This album did not give me the sensation i got from the rest of Paramore albums. So to anyone that liked Paramore's original style from previous albums such as Riot, this album may be a dud. i have to make one exception "I am into you" (thats why i gave it one star. One star for one good song the album had.

Like many, I had been looking forward to this album for years, and like many, I was concerned when I heard that the Farro Bros. left the band.  I was afraid the band would cease being Paramore and instead become The Hayley Williams Experience.  So were those fears warranted?  Sort of.I've listened Paramore (the album) probably 15-20 times now.  My first impression was that it was an eclectic collection of songs cobbled together non-cohesively.  Brand New Eyes, All We Know Is Falling, and, to a lesser extent, Riot, all seem to be relatively cohesive and have a generally consistent, poppy alternative rock style.  This album is largely a break from that formula.  Some songs sound a bit like they would fit in well on one of their older albums, but the bigger story is how many songs do not.  The album almost seems experimental at times, like Hayley is taking the opportunity in the absence of her former bandmates to branch out and see what she can do.  In general, most of the songs are more poppy than previous Paramore works, although some songs seem even heavier and deeper than you might expect (Track 17, "Future", comes to mind).So does it work?  For some people it may.  Ask yourself this -- when you buy a CD, do you typically pick a few tracks you like, listen to those, then pretty much ignore the rest of the disc?  If so, you will probably find a few tracks you like here.  If you're more likely to put in a CD, start it on track 1, and listen to it until it hits the end and your player spins down, you might be a little more frustrated by the constantly changing styles you will find here.  Personally, I fit in the latter group, so I was a little disappointed coming off of Brand New Eyes.  That's not to say there aren't some very good songs on this album -- there definitely are, and any true Paramore fan would be missing out by skipping it.  Still, it doesn't feel like it is on the same level as some of their previous works.Overall, this album isn't just a step in a new direction for Paramore, its a step in a lot of new directions.  I'm very interested to see where they go next -- do they return to their roots, continue to experiment, or do something different altogether?  I guess we'll just have to wait and see.Oh, and if you're reading this Hayley, I still love you :-)

I've been listening to Paramore since they were unknowns years ago. Paramore has always been one of the bands where I can literally listen to every single song and like it. The amazingly artistic instrumentals as well as amazing voice from Hayley is what sold me on this product. Their second album, brand new Eyes, was just as good as the first album. There are a couple of songs I would skip, but 8/10 of the songs are superb. They outdid themselves and lived up to the hype.This album however, does not suit my style at all. I find myself skipping almost every song on the list. About 2/10 of the songs I can bare continue listening to. Hayley still has the voice, but something has changed in the instrumentals and music. It's not as catchy. The style does not fit Paramore. They are moving towards a new direction for some reason and I don't like it. I would not recommend this album. Hopefully the next album they can produce the same music that made me love them.

First off, let me just say that I have been a fan of Paramore since they premiered "Pressure" on FUSE. I instantly fell in love with them, and they are one of my favorite bands, so this review COULD be a little biased as I truly love everything they do.Now that that's out of the way...This album is unlike anything else I've heard from them. If you are expecting rock from them, and you don't like pop music, you will not like this album. And that's fine! To each their own. I personally enjoy pop music, so I'm happy.As for the songs: "Hard Times" is easily the best single they have ever released. When I first heard it though I actually pushed pause a few seconds in because I could tell it was a HUGE departure from their previous work and I was NOT ready for it. Then, I collected myself, opened my mind a little, and listened. And guess what? I loved it. Super catchy. I have no idea why this song isn't a hit. It should be HUGE. So good." Told You So" had to grow on me a little. The video really made me love the song. It was what a true music video should be. It really highlighted the song and made me hear new things in it that I wouldn't have caught before.For me, the weakest song on the album is "Forgiveness." However, lyrically I can tell that this song was really important for the band. Musically though it just doesn't do anything for me, and it's surrounded by such good songs that I will probably skip it every time. With that said though, I do understand how important that song was to write and I understand why it's on the album.In my opinion, the success of this album has nothing to do with album sales, the success of this album is simply that it even exists. The band overcame a lot to make it, including some inner demons and insecurities, and I for one am just glad they created this! Even though it's pop and so different from what I expected, it seems really genuine to me.And yes, they have changed. They released their first album (and my favorite one) when they were TEENS. To that, I just want to ask, "Are you the same person you were when you were a teen?" I hope not! I know I'm not! Expecting a band to stay the same forever is ridiculous. Their instrumentation is SO much better now. They have grown so much and, for me, this is the most collaborative album they've put out. Even in interviews, it seems as though the other band members are speaking up more. People who have accused the band of being "Hayley's band" really need to go watch some interviews. Taylor had a huge role in this album, as did Zac. This album really feels like three best friends creating art together and I'm so happy they're happy.My faves are: Hard Times, Idle Worship, Told You So, 26, Tell Me How, Fake Happy, and No Friend. (I'm so glad they put "No Friend" on this album. It's awesome and different. Some people won't get it, but that's okay.) Also, I love that "Pool" sounds like a 90s love song. I miss that era of music so bad.Give this album a chance, and, at the very least, go check out 26 and Tell Me How! If you love their slow jams, these are GREAT.
