This album is considerably different than their previous albums - Not in a bad way, just different. I actually really love all of the songs!
I received the CD with a broken case. When I played the CD, all the songs started skipping.not acceptable.

I have been a Paramore fan for a long time now. They are actually my favorite band. With their previous albums there was tons of energy, charisma, and just plain old good music. When I found out that Josh and Zac Farro left the band I was devastated. They were both major assets to the band.When Paramore came out with their Singles EP without the Farro brothers I was hopeful. Their sound was still pretty much intact. I wasn't left disappointed. A little later "Now" came out. I liked it but it wasn't quite like the old Paramore. Then "Still Into You" came out and I was left a little disappointed. Both singles were great, but the signature sound was gone.Well, their CD came out and I bought it anyway. I have to say that the first listen through wasn't doing too much for me. There were some catchy songs here and there, but the Paramore I used to know was gone. Even Hayley's vocals have slightly changed. But the second time listening through it I realized that this album was extremely well written. The album flows so well together and it just puts you in a great mood. I realized that yes, it isn't the old Paramore, but it shouldn't have to be. These songs are amazing songs that get stuck in your head. I constantly find myself singing songs like "Grow Up," "Ain't It Fun," "Part II," and "Be Alone."So there you have it from a big fan who was slightly disappointed at first, I give this album five stars. Listen to it once, and then listen to it again and you'll find yourself loving it more and more with each listen. Each song is different so it is definitely not a boring album. They are still Paramore and still bring great music to the table.

I never thought I could be so disappointed in an album, but this one managed to do it. If you're looking old school Paramore then this isn't it.Pros:The lyrics tell a really good story.Hard Times & Told You so are probably the catchier songs (Singles)Hayley still has an amazing voice.Cons:It took me 4 years to get an album that veers off too far in the wrong direction.None of the tracks stand out other than the singles.While the lyrics are a story in itself, the instrumentals are mediocre at best.Too many filler type songs. Those songs that you usually might skip on an album is like every song on this album here.I really don't know what crowd this album is suppose to appeal to. The singles may do well enough, but the album as a whole doesn't hold up well. Is it trying to bring in different fans from other genres? At the very least the self-titled album introduced more pop while still providing some rock type songs, but this doesn't follow anything that they've had previously. Trust me when I say I wanted to like the album. I've listened to it 10+ times and at the end of the day it falls on the forgettable side. I wish them the best though.

When Paramore released their 2013 self-titled release, many were unsure what Paramore would sound like without the Farro brothers (who gave Paramore its distinctive sound).  The result was an album chocked full of variety and well written songs.  Songs with angst yet catchy like Fast In My Car, Now, and Ankle Biters mixed with poppy upbeat songs like Ain't It Fun, Still Into You, and Daydreaming that gave us a taste of 80's without overdoing it, and then slower songs like Hate To See Your Heartbreak that proved Hayley's talent at any tempo.  It was an album that showed that Paramore was here to stay.  Fast forward four years to the present and now I am left scratching my head.  While the self-titled album had some 80's sounds in various songs, it was not in full force and had just the right amount.  After Laughter, though, is a combination of indie-rock bands (think Coin, Walk The Moon, The 1975) with shimmering guitars but then a wall of noise trying way too hard to be something from the 1980's (with a whole lot of Blondie influences).  Now is this a bad thing?  That depends on what you like.  For me, I would be okay with it in moderation or in a few songs (I enjoyed Hard Times and Caught In The Middle).  But not one song on here in my opinion is near as good as the 7 songs I mentioned above from the self-titled album.  And there lies my main problem with this album.  It is forgettable and not something that I would put on to listen to from beginning to end.  And the fact that Zac Farro is back playing drums, his skills seem non-existent on the album except for the song No Friend, where he is the lone highlight of that odd song.  His under-utilization is reminiscent to MuteMath's "Vitals" where Darren King's skills were not on full display.  Here's to hoping that Hayley and Paramore return to their roots in their next album.

I truly only have positive things to say about this album. I grew up with Paramore, they were huge when I was in 6th grade and I loved them. This album has brought me into the excitement about them I used to have in middle school. It’s so refreshing to what they’ve made before and in contrast to other music as well. They created songs that I can dance around my room with, songs I cried to, and overall created an album that is great.Haley Williams is again a great reason for me even listening to Paramore and once again her vocals sound amazing. Her voice is so unique and it sounds amazing on every single track on the album. Her songwriting talent paired with the songwriting talent of the guitarist, Taylor York, is wonderful. The lyrics are fun, meaningful and overwhelmingly relatable.Even if you don’t like the complete album, I know there is at least a few songs for everyone. It is quality music from beginning to end.I can already tell this entire album will be on repeat for a long time.

review_title: The album to help you get through tough times
review_text: Paramore once again shows their dynamic ability to pump out completely unique albums and sounds. I'm a life-long Paramore fan and can understand why older fans might shy away from this once. This new ultra poppy, colorful 80s vibe Paramore has going isn't for everyone. But I promise if you really give it a try, you'll come away with plenty of enjoyment from a lot of songs on this album.Hayley Williams' vocals are on point, and there is a welcome return of founding member Zac Farro on drums. The sound pumps out colorful sounds of synth, funk, and electropop. The album speaks about present-day issues such as stress, tired small talk, depression, aging, among other themes, all in an ironic happy, groovy sound that'll make you forget how deep and sad the lyrics really can be.My personal favorites off this album are "Forgiveness", "Hard Times", "Fake Happy", "Rose-Colored Boy", and "Tell Me How", but I enjoyed the album in almost its entirety. It's a fun, ironic listen that might just be the solution for the struggles you're going through today.

review_title: So Far one of the best albums this year....
review_text: Paramore has always been a favorite in the pop punk scene, ranging from albums like Riot, Brand New Eyes, and their self titled album, as well as All We Know Is Falling. Now, Paramore have released a rather quick project called 'After Laughter' that gets it sound from stuff on an album from thr 80s, and the results are flawlessly perfect.Hard Times is the first single from the album, in which the change in direction of Sound was first noticed. Then, we get to songs such as 'Rose Colored Boy', something that sounds like a breezy synthpop Taylor Dayne, Madonna tune. Other favorites, 'Forgiveness', a much better remake of the badly awful Tears For Fears 'Everybody Wants To Rule The World', Fake Happy, a tune that begins sort of like a Sheryl Crow ballad, and then get into a catchy pop sound, '26', a mostly acoustic ballad, 'Grudges', a rock song that sounds a bit like a song from the Cure, and my favorite track on here 'Caught In The Middle', a 90s melodic tune that sounds extremely catchy. Other notable stuff on here is that a guy from MeWithoutYou sings on the song 'No Friend' and that every song have relatable lyrics on this album.This album is a phenomenal 97/100, even thought I loved albums like 'Riot' better. I think this album is a great listen, and kind of reminds me of when Carly Rae Jepsen decided to make an album based on the 80s ideaology, only that album was a perfect 100, and this Paramore record goes right below that, but still a purely fantastic listen.

review_title: Upbeat Music + Downbeat Lyrics = Addictively Catchy
review_text: How to define Paramore?  Are they pop?  Rock?  Something else entirely?  To be honest, I had always thought of them as catchy rock light, and liked them (or didn't) on a song-by-song basis.  "After Laughter" is the first album of theirs that I've listened to as an entire album; with that caveat, I'll boldly claim that it's a departure from their previous sound.  Although it has the same upbeat, infectiously energetic, synthetic background sound, the '80s influence is more strongly marked, and the wistful bittersweetness of the lyrics and vocals, which has always been there in the background, is more pronounced.  The contrast between the light, highly danceable music--with occasional forays into smooth acoustic territory, as in "26"--and the downbeat lyrics, with songs like "Hard Times" and "Fake Happy," could have been a terrible mismatch, but it works beautifully here: the lyrics on heartbreak, depression, and self-sabotage make the album more than just infectious candy pop, while the music takes what could have been a major downer of an album and makes it addictively listenable.The first part of the album is full of theme of heartbreak and depression, something the singer wants to acknowledge and experience fully, spurning the naive attempts on the part of others to convince her to cheer up (e.g., "Rose-Colored Boy") or forgive the transgressions of others ("Forgiveness").  Instead, she says, any happiness she's experiencing is faked ("Fake Happy").  It is not until the halfway point, song 6 in the 12-song album, in "26," that she is able to turn herself around a little, singing "Hold onto hope if you've got it/ Don't let it go for nobody."  In the next song, "Pool," she talks of diving back in--to an unhappy relationship.  In the subsequent songs, e.g., "Idle Worship," which has a return to the strident vocals typical of Paramore's earlier songs, it's the singer who is now the one letting down the other person in the relationship.  Although the album is not a concept album as such, it does contain a (vicious) cycle of hurt and heartbreak.If this sounds overly depressing, it's not--or at least, it's offset by the sunny musical sound, and the occasional flashes of hope, as in "26" and the closing track, "Tell Me How."  The lyrical voice of the album may not have relationships figured out yet, but she does seem to be figuring out herself, and learning how to withstand the ups and downs that life throws everyone's way.

review_title: Same Paramore with a slight mix of sounds from the 80's
review_text: When I first heard "Hard Times", I'm going to be honest I did not like it at all, and I've been a fan of Paramore since they first came out.I gave the song a second listen, and I still didn't like it - I was shocked because I always have liked their singles.I then saw a performance they did on TV of "Told You So" and I became even more upset because I didn't like the way that sounded either!Ultimately, I forced myself to purchase the album anyway and give it a shot since I've been a fan of theirs for so long, and now that I have listened to the full album a few times, I actually like it a lot! Hard Times DEFINITELY grew on me, and Told You So isn't bad either. My favorite songs/stand-out tracks IMO are:- Hard Times- Rose-Colored Boy- Fake Happy- 26This is definitely the same Paramore...their sound hasn't changed THAT much; there are just a few songs on this album that have an 80's type of vibe/style.

review_title: but the band had to pretend like they were okay when in the public eye
review_text: Paramore has been on the frontlines of pop punk music for years, with Hayley Williams solidifying herself as one of the premier female vocalists in modern rock music. That’s why when they took a new direction with their fifth studio album After Laughter fans were surprised with the direction it took. Moving away from the darker songs of past years, Paramore had a sound more reminiscent of the 1980’s on this record, showing a distinct change from the sound that brought them in to the national spotlight. The album has a big focus on Hayley Williams and her dealings with the rest of her group. For years, the media constantly spoke about Hayley Williams leaving the group to pursue solo projects, which created animosity in the group. Many members of Paramore had an issue with Hayley Williams being the only household name in the group. In past years, members have left the group, citing Hayley Williams being the main attraction as the reason for leaving. Thematically, this album takes a more somber approach to dealing with Williams’ emotions and how she has dealt with within group fighting for the past couple of years. One highlight of the album is “Fake Happy” which describes Williams talking about faking her emotions. She talks about putting up a façade and smiling on the outside when on the inside she isn’t. To me, I think this song draws connections to dealing with the drama in the group and how a lot of the fighting was happening behind the scenes, but the band had to pretend like they were okay when in the public eye. While this album does tackle some heavier subjects, there are also some songs that tackles these subjects in an upbeat way. “Hard Times” is an up-tempo song with a catchy chorus, but its subject matter goes a lot deeper. In interviews, Hayley Williams has talked about the meaning of the song, going on to say that it is about dealing with losing members of the band. Like stated before, Paramore has had numerous lineup changes over the years. This is taxing for the band as they constantly redefine their sound and roles in the band. After first listen, I didn’t even know the song had such heavy lyrics because I was too entranced by the melody and Hayley Williams electrifying voice over the smooth guitars. Being able to turn, for lack of a better phrase, hard times into something beneficial like music is important, and Hayley Williams for sure did this when she wrote “Hard Times” as she took the pain from her past and turned into a charting single. The whole album doesn’t just deal with Paramore band drama, it also deals with love and the beginning and ending of relationships. One song that does an especially good job of dealing with this subject is “Pool” a very well-produced song that uses imagery to express its message. Using water and waves as imagery, Hayley Williams talks about being how being in love is like drowning and being stuck underwater, but no matter what you are ready to “dive back into” the love at any moment. The song uses soft vocals and soft bass lines to give the song more of a love song feel, as opposed to an aggressive pop punk record. To me, the song is reminiscent of early 2000’s soft rock in how “unaggressive” it is. Unlike old Paramore projects, this song doesn’t throw the message in your face, it lets the listener unpack the meaning, using imagery to subtly express these feelings of love that Hayley Williams is so wrapped up in. The use of piano and synths on the track gives it an almost haunting sound, just like the haunting thought of drowning in love. I didn’t give this album a chance at first because I had heard rumors of how it was a stray from other Paramore records. I had been a fan of Paramore in my younger years, feeling that their pop punk, don’t care attitudes perfectly embodied the rebellion going on inside my teen mind. While this album did surprise me with how good it turned out to be, I do say that I miss the Paramore of days old. There weren’t any songs on this album I could imagine myself hearing live at Warped Tour and aggressively jumping up and down to. This album changed direction from previous Paramore works in many ways, and I truly would like to see them return to the sound that made them who they are today at some point down the line, but I respect artists changing up their sound for the sake of creative change. While most records on the album do a great job of making themselves stand out, songs like “26” and “Caught in the Middle” don’t do anything to stand out on the record. Personally, I think “Caught in the Middle” sounds way too much like “Fake Happy” and “26” is just flat out boring, not doing anything daring musically, making it seem like a filler track to me. I also was not a fan of the tropical “Tell Me How” which does not seem to fit in the Paramore discography. I personally do not want to hear Hayley Williams sing over a beachy beat, I want to hear her yelling over strong guitar riffs and loud drums. While this album differs from previous Paramore works, I think the album does a really good job of making the statement Hayley Williams intended it to. She expressed her feelings about the band, love, and her past in way that doesn’t make her seem like the invincible rock god she was on previous albums, but then again who is invincible.

What the hell is going on here? Did someone kidnap Paramore and replaced them with a mediocre pop band? I really want to know, cause this makes no sense to me. I understand a band's need for change, but at what cost? This sounds nothing like the Paramore I know and love. Where are the hard driving drums, guitars, and high energy sound? Where's Hayley's soaring vocals? What are they trying to accomplish with this drastic change in sound? I wouldn't have mind if this album was actually good, but it's surprisingly bad--almost painful to listen to! The shift is so extreme that it literally hurts my entire head. I don't know what they were thinking, but this is not one of their better ideas. This is not an album I will be purchasing or listening to for any length of time. I will still support the band, but not this album. It's just not very good.

review_title: Paramore delivers a recipe for disaster...And somehow it works
review_text: Why is this album so good? Usually when bands try to reinvent their sound out of nowhere, they fall flat on their faces. On top of that '80s style synthpop is one of the most infamous styles of pop music in the last several decades.So Paramore releases an album that reinvents their sound, completely guts a ton of their punk rock roots, and instead veers into '80s style synthpop...and somehow it's actually really good!Why is that the case? Well, possibly for the following reasons:1. Lots of the lyricism is some of the best the band has done. It can get deceptively heavy and deep in many spots, and the contrast between it and the lighter music is executed really well.2. Hayley Williams' vocals and the instrumentation from Taylor York and Zac Farro is as fantastic as ever.3. Despite being inspired from a genre infamous for being generic and often substanceless, there is a ton of meat in the musicality on this album.4. A general high level of consistency.My favorite song is easily Fake Happy.No Friend is probably the only song on here I just don't like. It just doesn't belong and feels like it way overstays its welcome.Definitely give this album a listen. It's always disappointing hearing artists completely lose their touch, so it should be refreshing when Paramore succeeds so well in this new direction.

review_title: One of the Year's Pleasant Surprises
review_text: Paramore returns after a four year hiatus with the release of 2013's self-titled effort Paramore.  After `09s successful Brand New Eyes, things from an outward perspective seemed to be falling apart for the band, just as success continued to mount.  The exit of the Farro brothers left the question about the future livelihood and lucrativeness of the band, stripped to a trio including Hayley Williams, Taylor York, and Jeremy Davis.  The results end up greatly exceeding expectations, as Paramore is one of the year's better and hottest albums. Add to those accolades a number one debut on the charts, and the coronation is complete.  Justin Meldal-Johnsen handles the production work."Fast In My Car" sets the tone, laden with hefty guitar work, pummeling drums, and feisty vocals from Hayley Williams.  "We're driving fast in my car / we've got our riot gear on but we just want to have fun...", she sings enthusiastically on the chorus.  "Now", similarly, is a ball of energy, finding Williams in tongue-in-cheek mode, stretching out vocal syllables: "if there's a future, we want it / Now-ow-ow...". "Grow Up" is arguably the best of a fine opening trio, featuring solid songwriting, catchy chorus, and a whiny, invested Williams.  Throw in some 80s synths at the conclusion for good measure, and "Grow Up" is rock solid."Daydreaming" is equally catchy and memorable, one of the true gems; it benefits from thoughtful development and overall pacing.  After a ukelele-accompanied interlude, the show-stopping "Ain't It Fun" gives Paramore one of their best songs, EVER.  The gospel-infused choral vocals truly propel during the vamped sections ("Don't go crying to your mama / cause you're on your own in the real world..."). "Part II" proceeds consistently, while "Last Hope" impresses with its balance of push and pull, not to mention Jeremy Davis's active bass line.  "Still Into You" once more nods to the 80s, with Williams's personality at its most magnetic."Anklebiters" is as assertive in sound as it's clever title suggests.  Uptempo punk at it's best, the song isn't even among the best on this ultra consistent set.  Following another ukelele-driven interlude, "Proof" possesses a jungle-like quality, given its pounding drums.  It falls short of the elite, but its follow-up "Hate To See Your Heart Break" makes the cut, showing William's more tender vocal side.  She and the band contrast smoothness for the `crazed' on "(One of Those) Crazy Girls" in which Williams is quick to state "I'm not one of those crazy girls..." However after a revealing chorus ("Baby are we over now? Maybe I can change your mind? As soon as you walk out my door / I'm gonna call a hundred times"), the end finds Williams accepting her fate ("Now I'm one of those crazy girls").A final interlude precedes "Be Alone", which is a typical Paramore cut (driving, dirty guitars, Williams assertive).  Closer "Future" is more experimental, featuring vocals early on, but conceding most of its duration to instrumental ideas.  All in all, Paramore ends up being an unexpected surprise.  If anything, the exits of Josh and Zac Farro only fueled the fire of the trio, who truly compel to the upmost here.  Enthusiastically recommended.

review_title: I've heard better music in elevators
review_text: They ditched the guitar and bass in favor of various doctor's office hold music. It's Paramore in name alone, but if you like their old music just keep listening to their old music.

review_title: One of the strongest albums of 2013.
review_text: Nearly 15 months after Paramore's fourth LP was released (April 9, 2013), the band remains as brilliantly defiant as ever.  Unfortunately, as most fans know, Paramore had suffered a 3 year hiatus because of the Farro brother's absence (the 2 brothers left the band of their own volition because of religious/irreconcilable differences).  Now a quartet, Paramore actually sound BETTER for it.  The entire album is much stronger, faster, louder and looser than their previous recordings.  If the one-two punch of "Fast In My Car" and "Now" doesn't convince anyone that Paramore is here to stay, then just wait until you hear the rest of it.  :)Now I'm going to talk about my personal, most sacred favorite tracks on this record.  First, "Grow Up" sounds like a potential kiss off to all the haters -- "Everybody has to grow up sometimes.../If you don't, I'm gonna leave you behind."  Next, I love the 3 acoustic guitar interludes from Hayley, which seem to reflect on her current feelings about past and present life in general."Ain't It Fun" -- this song just SCREAMS "number one hit".  I love the playful, melodic xylophone twinkle at the beginning of the song, right before the crunchy guitars kick in.  And the best part is the choir at the bridge/ending of the song, coupled with Hayley throwing down some serious, mean, soulful vocals!  It can't get much better than that.  :)"Still Into You" -- still in heavy radio rotation, this song was written about Hayley's current boyfriend.  I can't stop dancing to this song (even if I wanted to), whether I'm at home or driving on the interstate/freeway.  And, my favorite part of the song is the bridge where the extra percussion kicks in.  It just makes you want to get up and MOVE!!  :)"Anklebiters" -- the band's most punk rock anthem ever, not to mention the shortest.  They pulled it off, once again, with aplomb."Proof" and "Be Alone" -- more great and familiar melodies that are also surefire hits.Lastly, what causes Paramore to stand out is their live shows.  They have endless bounds of energy and the fans completely feed off of it.  I'm looking forward to their next record -- hopefully we'll get to see one by 2015 or 2016.  I can't wait!!  :)

I am admittedly a newcomer to Paramore.  This 2013 self-titled opus is my first album from them.  I read an article about the band in the local newspaper here and they sounded interesting, a Christian pop-punk/rock band, and then I saw the CD in the new releases rack at Kmart and decided to take the plunge and buy it.  I'm so glad I did.I find frontwoman Hayley Williams to be a very interesting individual.  She is a woman, undeniably very attractive physically, and yet she is 100% convincing as a genuine social misfit/outcast.  I am hit or miss about actually taking the time to read the lyrics to CDs that I buy, but I found Hayley's lyrics here to be very personal, sincere and human.  I also feel a kinship with her because she was born under the astrological sign Capricorn, just as I was, and we in this sign are known to sometimes be misunderstood and reclusive homebodies/introverts.  Hayley's lyrics to "Be Alone" read her like a book:  "What if I don't ever want to leave my house?/Stay on the couch while all my friends are going out.""Be Alone" is by the way probably my favorite song here.  It's so honest and real.  It's the second to last song on the CD, and I find the album's second half to be the stronger of the two, as it also has the great second single "Still Into You."  I can see why this song propelled the album all the way to the top of the charts for a time in April.  It's that good.  "Proof" has a chorus so catchy you will not get it out of your head for days.  And finally, the ballad that follows it "Hate to See Your Heart Break" is very soothing and emotionally rich, sounding like it would not be out of place on good Adult Contemporary radio.All in all, a great, positive leaning CD with lyrics you can really feel and tunes you can readily sing along to.  Highly recommended.

There is no album that I have listened to as many times as After Laughter.  The lyrics are gripping while the melodies are intoxicating.  This body of work is every bit as important as a great piece from Mozart or a classic rock album.  It is a masterpiece!

review_title: I Enjoyed Paramore Before And I Enjoy Them Now-ow-ow-ow-ow-ow-ow-ow
review_text: I have to admit it, I was a fan of the Farro Brothers.  The two brothers had such a distinctive sound with Josh's shimmering guitar tones and Zac's attacking approach to the drums.  And while that is missed on this album, Haley Williams and Company have plunged ahead with an enjoyable bag of treats, albeit a mixed bag at times.1. Fast In My Car (10/10): Starts out with a cool little guitar riff.  It's a fun song while at the same time it is a proclamation of who they are now as a band and their new outlook.  It's basically a song about moving on and their "drive" to do it.  It's Paramore at the their energetic best.2. Now (10/10): The first single from the new album shows you that Paramore is here to stay.  It has fuzzy guitars, killer vocals, and a mantra of "If there's a future, we want it NOW."  It is song of rebirth that is full of hope and adrenaline.3. Grow Up (8/10): Very poppy and it makes me wonder if Haley is channeling her inner Gwen Stefani.  Is this a song a response to Eisley's "Sad" that is supposed to be about Haley dating Sherri Dupree's ex, New Found Glory's Chad Gilbert?  Some may think so but I see it as another song in a theme-filled album about maturing and moving on from the past.4. Daydreaming (10/10): As much as I love an energetic Paramore, this slow pop song gets me every time.  I love the music build up and Haley's vocals sound great.  Has a bit of an 80's feel, maybe even a little bit of a Blondie feel to it.5. Interlude: Moving On (7/10): As I mentioned before, there is a theme about maturing and moving on, so it is fitting to have a song called Moving On.  This is one of several interludes with Haley and an ukulele and this is the strongest one.  With lyrics like what follows, it seems clear that it is a song directed at the Farro brothers: "Let 'em play their song, let 'em say what's right and wrong. Let 'em do their thing, cause it'll never be you and me. We got out own style, we got a way of living life. If they can't get down, well then we don't need them around. Well I could be angry, but you're not worth the fight and besides I'm moving on. I've counted to 10 and now I'm feeling all right. And besides I'm moving, yes I'm moving, besides I'm moving on."6. Ain't It Fun (10/10): An 80's sounding funky dance/pop song, this is another song that sounds different for Paramore and yet it works.  I love the sarcastic chorus of: "Ain't it fun living in the real world?"  A very cool bridge as well.  The highlight of the album.7. Part II (5/10): Part II is in reference to being a newly re-written version of "Let The Flames Begin."  It is almost as if Paramore is saying we still have our Christian faith intact and that we still have the struggles as all Christians have.  As a fan of the original song, I have to say that I am less of a fan of this version.  It does make you miss the Farro brothers when you hear it.8. Last Hope (8/10): Part II does transition nicely into this song, a song about hope and faith.  I love the lines: "It's just a spark but it's enough to keep me going. And when it's dark out and no one's around it keeps glowing."  It's another slower song that builds nicely and the guitar tones are reminiscent of what Josh Farro would write.9. Still Into You (9/10): A nice love song.  Catchy and cutesy.  If the guitars were a little heavier, I think I would have enjoyed it a little more.  This is definitely a song that when you listen to it, you realized just how much Zac Farro's drumming is missed.10. Anklebiters (8/10): Paramore picks up the pace and that might be an understatement.  This song is a nice little punk tune about society's attack on people.  Haley is declaring that she is over all these "anklebiters" and is done trying to please everyone.  It goes along with the recurring theme of moving on as a band and as a person.11. Interlude: Holiday (3/10): Another interlude song about moving on and getting a deserved break.  It is short and seems like a filler track (though with 17 tracks total, it is hard to complain).12. Proof (8/10): This song has some cool guitar lines and cool drum beats with a lot of energy.  Seems like a song about long distance relationships which she has a lot of experience in.  About 2/3 of the way into, it gets a nice bouncy feel to the song.13. Hate To See Your Heart Break (9/10): A slower song that uses Haley's lower range.  This has the feel of a country pop song.  I could hear it being used as a country song on the TV show "Nashville" or hear a country artist do this song.  I like the emotion in Haley's voice during the chorus.  A very different sound for Paramore but for a group that maturing and moving on, I think it is great.  There is nothing better than a band that can excel at upbeat songs AND slower songs.14. (One Of Those) Crazy Girls (5/10): I'm not crazy about (One Of Those) Crazy Girls.  It does have an interesting slow start that speeds up, but not one of my favorites.15. Interlude: I'm Not Angry Anymore (3/10): Another song about Josh Farro?  At this point, we could all care less since I thought we were moving on.16. Be Alone (8/10): This is one of the more old-Paramore sounding songs.  Nice sounding drums and guitars and Haley's outstanding vocals. Both catchy and energetic, it comes at just the right time in the album.17. Future (7/10):  "We don't talk about the past; we don't talk about the past now."  Well, I don't know if that is true but this is a decent ending to an above average album.  The song reminds of the way Anberlin likes to end albums except I wish Paramore had built it into this rocking, epic finale.  Even though the music ends and then they come back in, I feel like they could have and should have gone out a little bigger.In conclusion, I enjoyed this mixed bag of treats.  Sure, there were some lows but there were a lot of high moments.  One thing I did love is although I have been such a fan of Paramore's upbeat/energetic songs, there were some slower songs here that really stuck with me.  And whatever your opinion of Haley, you have to admit she has one of the best vocals out there and proves that she is not limited to a certain genre.  As far as her and the Farro brothers are concerned, I believe there are three sides to every story: hers, theirs, and the truth somewhere in the middle.  We can wonder why Haley was signed before the rest of the band, but at the end of day, Haley chosen then and NOW that she longs to be in a band and not a solo artist.  And I am grateful for that choice.

Firstly, as a Paramore fan since the beginning, every album has been slightly better than the last. In this case, I would say not only is it Paramore's best album by a long shot, it's a darn fine album for ANY artist to be proud of. The adult woman in me REALLY appreciates Haley's matured voice in these tracks, while the angsty teen leftovers of me still enjoy the more old school feel Paramore songs like "Be Alone", "Anklebiters" and "Still Into You".I'm always wary of albums with interludes, but actually I LOVE all three on this album, and wish they were full songs! They remind me a bit of Ingrid Michaelson, and I'm glad she was able to open up lyrically and not be afraid of sounding anti-Christian. Maybe it was best for the Farro brothers to go.The album closer, "Future" is very lovely and progressive, like a rock lullaby. If I were to just hear the guitar/drum work at the end of it randomly, I would never know this was Paramore. It reminds me of Deftones, Tool, etc, and it's very cool.One of the best tracks for me was "(One Of Those) Crazy Girls", because it's a great example of a creepy but upbeat song. It actually reminds me a lot of Alanis Morissette's Jagged Little Pill album closer/hidden track "Your House" & has a dreamy sound towards the end. "Part II" is like a mix of Sia's style, and Freur's "Doot Doot". I think it might be Haley's best vocal moment ever at the songs ending. "Last Hope" is more of a background song, and is similar to something the band Fun would do. While I didn't much care for "Daydreaming", "Last Hope" & "Proof", I don't mind sitting through them as they flow through the album.My favorite tracks I think stand out the most (and are the most fun/singable) are "Fast In My Car", "Now", "Grow Up", and the best ballad they've ever done, "Hate To See Your Heartbreak". I can just picture this song in a movie or tv show scene, or a music video with slowed-down tour moments. For someone who can't stand country, I think it uses the proper elements of it, and makes it better. It actually reminds me a little of the band Eisley.All in all, this is my new favorite album to listen to, Haley sounds the best she ever has, and  everything the band has done up to this point was meant to make an album like this. I'm glad they ventured out and proved they could keep getting better.

I've been a fan of Paramore for a long time, I even saw them for the first time on their first tour.  I know it can be hard to adjust to a change in a band's sound for some, but this is the perfect evolution.  The album is a triumph.  The lyrics so candidly talk about depression and being sad in ways other bands and artists have failed.  Having recently gone through some "Hard Times," I can tell you that this record is a godsend.  When I really connect with an artist or album, I feel it...and After Laughter brings the feels.  Depression is real & common & should be talked about in a more open manner.  Thank you Paramore.

I have loved Paramore since their first album.  This latest album just doesn't cut it.  To each their own, but the songs feel cheap and silly.  I agree with another reviewer, in that i wonder just who this album is aimed for ? It's certainly a dis-service to their long time followers.  Just my opinion.  Your milage may vary.

review_title: Its kind of wimpy for Paramore
review_text: Underwhelmed just about says it all. It seems like they were declawed. This album is so heavy on the radio-friendly poppy tracks its almost annoying. Yes, Paramore has always had a partly-pop formula, but this time around its less rock and attitude than I ever would have hoped for. Some may argue its a more mature step but I disagree completely. With the exception of a few tracks, the songs feel lazy, uninspired, and teeny-boppery 9that's a word right?) i guess. Its missing that spark. I fear we are seeing the slow but inevitable transformation of Paramore into Haley Williams solo. Don't miss understand, the songs aren't terrible, but a good part of them aren't for me. They are a great band and are capable of much better.

review_title: More upbeat and pop than usual, less intense and rock :(
review_text: I think my opinion of this album is really affected by my expectations of Paramore. Until this album came out, I LOVED almost every Paramore song. Ironically, the one I didn't like was "The Only Exception." Their songs had so much energy and they had a great rock sound. After they lost two of their members, I didn't know what would become of the band. Then the band released "Monster" and it was an awesome song and I was really excited to see what they'd do next. This album disappointed me because it's not the same Paramore I expected. Songs sound more upbeat and pop, and not as intense and rock as usual. Maybe it's working for them because "Still Into You" is probably their most popular song ever, but it's not what I'm used to hearing as a huge Paramore fan.UPDATE:It took a while but now I'm thinking the album is decent. I still maintain that they've changed their sound, with "Part II" being the only one to resemble their original sound, but I've grown to like half of the songs on the album. Four stars out of respect for the band(:

as i feared, the black and white marble is 98.5% black with some grey which overall just makes it look dirty.  it's almost as if those who ordered earlier got the nicer mixed ones. why make something with such a variation!

Not sure if it's because i'm 26 years old, or their sound has aged very well..  Listening to this band circa 2004-2005 when hardcore/emo music was in, you can definitely tell they have matured. Matured like fine wine.  The cd itself is tight and the instruments sound very clean.Haley's voice is always wonderful as others have stated, however she does dig outside the rock/alternative vibe and experiments with soulful/RNB type vocals (listen to "aint no fun"; has an old school 90's vibe).Overall this is a great cd, and is worth every penny.  This is someone who's listened to paramore from the beginning, I feel their change is great.  I appreciate the direction they're going.  Purchase this cd, you will not be disappointed.

This is Paramore's best album in my opinion. I basically like every song on this album! The self titled deluxe version (basically the deluxe version of this album w/ a few new songs & some live songs too) that just came out is awesome also if you don't mind getting it on MP3 format because they didn't make it on actual cd format /: which is ok! But I know some people prefer having a physical copy so just a heads up on that one! But either way this album is amazing! Still listening to it a lot & it came out well over a year ago :) You won't be disappointed with either version! ;)

review_title: Great departure from their previous work
review_text: I've been listening to Paramore for a very long time and this is definitely their most fun album to date! It's a departure from their previous work but they still kept that special thing that makes them awesome. Hayley's vocals are superb! The album is young, free, happy, and even though some of the songs have not-so-happy themes, they're done in super up-beat tunes. I just wanna drive down a long highway with my windows down on a sunny day blasting this, as cheesy as that sounds, haha. Also, I recently saw them live and I was ecstatic to hear they sound even better live! It's just so awesome when you see a band live and they're everything you expected (and more)!

I was really confused as to some of the negative reactions that Paramore received from their previous album, the self titled one from 2013.  At least one person on here accused them of "going" bubble-gum pop.  I did not see it that way.  It was the same first energy and pop-punk craftiness that attracted me to 2007's RIOT!  The inclusion of some synths didn't bother me and I barely even noticed it except on the opening segment of the opening track.  This album does indeed see Paramore bowing out of the poppunk arena.  I still would not call this "bubble gum" pop, but it's a lot more smooth and a little more laid back than their prior albums.  I was mortified when I first heard this.  But after awhile i found myself singing to the air snippets of "Rose colored boy" while cleaning the toilet. And I thought why not give it another chance?  Its no magnum opus.  Maybe this is to their new chapter what ALL WE KNOW IS FAILING was to their 1st 1.  I still an not crazy about that first effort.  Maybe Paramore will do this again and break through with an equivalent to "Misery Business".

review_title: Hayley Williams and two guys make an album
review_text: Be very clear before you purchase this that this is not the Paramore you know.  This is Hayley Williams' debut solo album.  Riot! in my opinion was one of the best punk/rock/whatever you want to call it albums ever made. Having said that, this new album is not bad.  Hayley obviously wanted a different direction and she does it here.  It is much more reminiscent of No Doubt's ska pop sound.  It is most definitely not a set you'd expect to hear on the Vans Warped tour.  Riot! was perfection for me, and for many fans.  A shame the band members couldn't get through their 'teen and early 20s' angst and keep things going musically.  Here's to hope that in about five years or so they'll get back together and get back to the basics which made Paramore so incredibly popular in the first place.

review_title: The album is great, MUST BUY!
review_text: This is my song review one by one  just in my own opinion. Buy the album and check em' out.Fast In My Car: 7/10Now: 8/10 This reminds of me their old stuff, it brings back memories but also with something new in it.Grow Up: 7/10 Upbeat song, its cuteDaydreaming: 8/10 Its a really catchy song, Not my favorite on the album but i always find myself singing it out loud.Interlude: Moving On: 10/10 I love all the interludes, they're great and wish they could all be longer.Ain't it fun: 9/10 Great song to just dance in your room toPart II: 10/10 My opinion, best song on the album. Its just beautiful and lovely hearing the contrast between Let The Flames Begin on the Riot album and Part II of the song which is this one.Last Hope: 10/10 Slow song, but awesome lyrics and really nice to listen toStill into you: 10/10 First song i heard from the album, and i loved how Paramore-y it sounded and how different it sounded at the same time. SUPER upbeat, and such a change but i loved it.Anklebiters: 8/10 Not bad, catchy again but not my favoriteInterlude:Holiday 10/10 Love the interludes.Proof: 8/10 Pretty soft rock, not much to say about this oneHate to see your heart break: 8/10 One of those soft songs, its nice and sweet and sad. i like her voice in this oneInterlude: I'm not angry anymore: 10/10 INTERLUDE!Be alone: 9/10 love to sing to this song!Future: 10/10 One of my favorite songs. Its long but its beautiful. its a lot of instrumental, but worth it. its soft and melodic, the sound it just so great!The album is definitely worth it. GO AND BUY IT! :)

Thank u Slacker radio for highlighting this as album of the week allowing me to listen to it entirely. I've been a paramore fan since decode and I feel like I've grown up with them. I really enjoyed their self titled and this is jus as good. I've listened to it from start to finish 3 or 4 times today w/o skipping one song! Forgiveness has a total Tears for Fears vibe to it. Also really love rose colored boy, pool, plus idle worship & no friends r hypnotic. CANT WAIT TO PURCHASE THIS ALBUM.

I don't pound on the table screaming for the old Paramore. I loved the last album. After Laughter is a little boring. Dynamically, it's too cool throughout (as opposed to hot).There's a lot I like about the album. It's an easy listen. It flows well from song to song. I think it opens well and closes strongly. Panic over Paramore's demise is greatly exaggerated.

My feelings about the new Paramore album:During my first listen I was expecting to hear the SAME Paramore from "All We Know", "Riot", & "Brand New Eyes" & all Paramore purists out there will probably do the same. But it's not the same Paramore from those previous masterpieces & I should've known that being that the Farros who began this group are no longer a part of the band. All that being said & after giving it another listen without those expectations I still really like this new album. It offers A LOT of different sounds, but even though its different if you listen closely enough there is still some of that classic Paramore swag there. I would not say that they remain Paramore, its clear that they are something else, but I'm willing to give this new band a try & look forward to what their future holds.Favorites include (in order of tracklisting):1. Fast In My Car2. Now6. Ain't it Fun (in my opinion this has a really different song especially with the choir at the end but its such a fun and happy song)7. Part II9. Still into You (give it a chance. Its the most "pop" of the songs in my opinion and it really serves its purpose of being a happy love song about her bf from New Found Glory)10. Anklebiters12. Proof13. Hate to See Your Heart Break (this song is on the line of "The Only Exception", not as good sounding but lyrically is a good love song)14. One of those Crazy Girls (retro-sounding song)17. Future (What I love about this song is that it starts off so simplistic but by the end evolves into this HARD guitar focused outro as if meshing together the "new Paramore" with the past as they set their sights on their evolution)But these are just my thoughts, if you are expecting the old Paramore you wont blatantly find that here. If you are willing to find out what this new Paramore is all about & aren't going to shun the album on the first round I think you'd be pleasantly surprised by what you find here...

After a long wait for the new album it has finally arrived.  I was curious to hear the direction Paramore would be heading on their latest effort.  While it may not have the impact of their previous work, it still is a decent record.  This latest album may be missing some of the alternative rock sound and replaced it with pop-rock. I would rate the music around a b- and the lyrics around a c-, although Hayley's voice and vocal patterns make up for some of the imperfections.  It feels very polished and produced almost too much, which seems stale at times. For the fans who are expecting "All We Know Is Falling" or "Riot" type records I think you will be a little disappointed.  Those who appreciate an album redefining the idea of what Paramore's music means. This will be an alright record to check out.  Personally I feel this album will be worth playing for a month or two but won't be replayed very frequently after.  "Fast In My Car", "Now", "Ain't It Fun", and "Still In To You" are the highlights of the album.

This is not old Paramore.  Is that important?  Yes.  No, it's not a slam; two of the founding members have left so yes it's kinda obvious that it will sound different without them.  So where are Paramore as a group?  The album proves that no one is irreplaceable, so this album is a hearty "wave goodbye" to the disenchanted brothers.  The fact that Paramore has soldiered on - indeed successfully - has nailed the doubt issue.  Yes, they can survive.  A lot of new textures and grooves are here and if you're expecting "That's What You Get" or "Misery Business" you're going to be left out in the cold.  Again...new band members.  So the old groove ain't gonna be there.  Having said that, the new stuff - tho different - is easily some of their best work ever.  Haley's voice goes in to some strange territory on a few numbers but she's still on form and still able to pound out the new material with conviction and feeling.  There are a ton of excellent songs here both to keep old fans and draw new ones in.  "Daydreaming" is easily the best song released this year by anyone.  "Proof," "Ain't It Fun" and "Part Two" are excellent, catchy songs.  Out of five stars, I give this sixteen.

First time I listened to this album, I was a bit disappointed that it didn't have the same elements from Riot and Brand New Eyes. Then, I listened to the album a few more times and found myself really enjoying this evolution of their music style. My favorite songs from this album are: Anklebiters, Grow Up, Part II, Still Into You and all of the Interlude titled tracks.If you're on the fence about purchasing the album, I would recommend listening to the tracks a few times because this is a change from the previous albums. I think that you'll find, like me, this is a purchase you won't regret making.

I downloaded this album and then when I was driving out of town I put all my Paramore albums on shuffle. All the songs from this album stuck out, and not in a good way. I would be jamming out to Hallelujah or CrushCrushCrush or something similar and then one of these songs would come on and I seriously would be like what the heck is this. I tried to listen and give it a chance, but I never made it through to the end of any of the songs without wanting to go back to their older albums, which I do really like. I don't know how this can be called Paramore - the sound is COMPLETELY different. I personally don't like it, but I can see how this might get them into some new markets. If you're looking for a new Paramore album, you're out of luck. This is a completely different band.

review_title: She is maturing.. I like it.
review_text: I like the lyrics on "Idol Worship" I guess she is pulling up the thoughts in her head of who she used to be before she became a singer. If your honest with yourself and are sincere about changing.. It can happen! But it takes humility, faith, work.

A really good album. Can't get enough of grudges, pool, fake happy and rose colored boy! The genre change will take some time getting used to but I think everyone will love it after a few months like the other 4

review_title: You'll like this album, if you can forget that it's Paramore
review_text: Paramore as we know it is dead. With Hayley's songwriting partner gone (lead guitarist Josh Farro), as well as the departure of their dynamic drummer (the slugging Zac Farro), this band has no choice but to take on a new identity.Taylor York takes Josh Farro's songwriting place, but it's bass player Jeremy Davis who steps up and gives a huge personal performance, introducing an r&b groove that's an acquired taste to rock fans but nicely done.This album is more of a new alternative record -- you can hear colors of the yeahyeahyeahs and newer Tegan and Sara. There's danceability, really strong lyrics in spots and very strong vocals. But Paramore is pop-punk and this record is not.At first I was confused as to why they self titled a record to identify a gutted band, but I guess it was to make an example that they didn't quit on Paramore.With Tegan and Sara moving towards sentimental groovy rock, and Taylor Swift coming more towards alternative music, I'm not ready for Hayley to get away from her high-energy, biting intensity. She definitely leaves a void.Highlights (in track order): Fast in my Car, Daydreaming, Ain't it Fun, Still into You, Proof

This album reminds me of 80s pop music, certainly not what I expect to hear from Paramore.  Even their self-titled was a change from previous albums, but it was still rock music and it grew on me.  This one was intolerable pop music.  The first two tracks were the only ones I could stomach, and they're the only reason I rated it 2 stars instead of 1 star.Glad I picked it up at the library to try out instead of buying it.Hello Paramore.  Welcome to the land of pop.  Please have a seat over there beside Katy Perry, Britney, and Taylor Swift.Final thought: Disappointed

I love the way Paramore is evolving. They can still rock and Hayley can wail, but they're also bring some new things to the table and are not afraid to experiment. It's a surprise and a delight. Can't wait to see where they take us next. For those struggling with their evolution, open your mind and give the album a few listens and you may find there's more here than you thought.

A fine, intelligent, fun, did i say fun?! Progression. Taking what was done with the last album and bringing something familiar and FUN and new to the table, the 80s are alive and well in Paramore and in this generation. Absolutely nailed it! Hailey you rule, and what a relief the original drummer, dare i say swing master and groove innovator! is back! The drummer for Underoath did an outstanding job live, but the throne is now reclaimed! The guitar work on this album is evolutionary. Hailey takes melody, imagination, flow and range to a whole new level! A++++ i love this record! Cannot wait to see them live!

Been a fan of Paramore since the beginning.  This album is much different from their others, but it is amazing.  I have heard some people speak negatively about this new sound, but if you miss the old Paramore then listen to the old Paramore!  The band has evolved, and personally, I love this new sound.  I have been listening to After Laughter on repeat since it came out.  It's been a while since I wanted to listen to an entire album without skipping any tracks, but I just let it play.  It's got plenty of bangers as well as some slow jams!  I highly recommend it!!!!

review_title: Give it a couple of listens
review_text: Different from their previous albums for sure. "After Laughter" has an 80s electronic feel to it. Still with a lot of catchy melodies. As usual Ms. Williams delivers strong vocals. At first listen, none of the songs are particularly memorable. However, after a couple of listens to get used to this new sound, this is a truly solid album.

review_title: wish i could get a refund...
review_text: Not sure what went wrong here, sounds like some guys left the band? i'm not a country music fan...I'm not a folk music fan...and this album is a mix of both...I'm sure they're still very talented, they just put out one terrible album...

review_title: Ugh.  'After the sleeping pills' would be a better title.
review_text: Sorry, but except for Hard Times, this is lame.I haven't been this disappointed since Laroux's 2nd CD or LIttle Boots' 2nd CD.  Haley's voice is still excellent, although she doesn't sing as much as tell stories like a poetry reading. The music is lifeless.And I miss the ukulele interludes- see their previous CD- which was fantastic!

review_title: Fantastic Band with another Fantastic Album
review_text: Great album, fast delivery! One of my favorite bands. Check out song Fake Happy it's excellent!

"After Laughter" is great. This is another great album from Paramore. It is solid, well-done and entertaining. All (12) tracks on here are great.Track Listing:1. Hard Times (4 out of 4 stars)2. Rose-Colored Boy (4 out of 4 stars)3. Told You So (4 out of 4 stars)4. Forgiveness (4 out of 4 stars)5. Fake Happy (4 out of 4 stars)6. 26 (4 out of 4 stars)7. Pool (4 out of 4 stars)8. Grudges (4 out of 4 stars)9. Caught In The Middle (4 out of 4 stars)10. Idle Worship (4 out of 4 stars)11. No Friend (4 out of 4 stars)12. Tell Me How (4 out of 4 stars)

This album is one of the best albums of all time. Honestly, I've never been more happy while dealing with so many crappy things at once- and I can't thank Paramore enough for continuing to exist and share themselves with the world.

review_title: This may be my favorite Paramore album
review_text: This may be my favorite Paramore album...80s influence combined with the slightly dark lyrics on a lot of the songs. It's a very cohesive record from start to finish. I"m currently listening to "Fake Happy", "Pool", and "Grudges" on repeat. I love the little "woo!" before the chorus on "Grudges".

I've been hooked on Paramore since 2007, when Riot broke them into the mainstream. They matured slightly but maintained a pretty similar pop/punk/happy rock sound on Brand New Eyes, another successful album. Since then they've seen lineup changes and taken things in quite a different direction. I certainly hope they won't go further down this road, and I'll try to elaborate why in my review."Fast In My Car" opens the album up, and already the band is on half steam. They throw on some poorly concocted riffs and Hayley makes it through the song, but there is absolutely nothing about it that stands out as interesting or memorable. The first single "Now" follows, while this one has grown on me, it sounds kind of like they recorded their instruments on seperate continents and threw it all together later. The song is sort of shambling indie rock, only the vocals keep it from toppling over. "Grow Up" is another song about someone (a guy who hurt you, Hayley?) who will not grow up, but Paramore are certainly growing up and moving on in the world, look at them go! They've nagged this theme to death on Brand New Eyes already (but at least back then it was set to good music). "Daydreaming" is another song sure to grind your gears, it's more like musical nagging than any melodic, awesome kind of rock. I'll sum up every last interlude on the album with my thoughts on the first, "Moving On"; it's a pointless, distracting, pretentious, wafty piece of filler with Hayley strumming a ukulele and trying to sound incredibly profound. If you have to pack the album with this musical bubble wrap, at least make it a little different - add some different instruments, lead into a song, anything at all. "Ain't It Fun" sounds like a rejected Michael Jackson song - a kind of Caribbean wedding muzak piece. It should pick up and go somewhere, but it doesn't. "Part II" is the spiritual successor to a far better song - "Let The Flames Begin". They prod at the wound only to remind us they were once a great band, by destroying their own music, it only adds insult to injury. It unfortunately sounds like a very half-butted indie rock version, and I say that very sincerely - they've sucked out every single part of it that was good, strong and catchy and replaced it with trudging drum machines and meaningless strumming on guitar strings. "Last Hope" is another interlude with drums and that same excuse for guitar work again, it's not a song, don't be fooled. Then, at last, comes the highlight of the album. "Still Into You" is an absolutely amazing song. It's everything this album should have been and more. It's got energy, it's got emotion, it's got joy, power and speed, and they actually play guitar and drums on the track! It's infectious, rocky, poppy, it's everything good and right about Paramore. It's the only solid reason to listen to the album whatsoever, and a single that will live on long after the album collects dust in bargain bins all over the world. "Anklebiters" follows it, and it's Paramore by the numbers. It's supposed to be fun and infectious but it just comes off as a little obnoxious. Then there's a track called "Proof", which I had forgotten about. That says pretty much everything about that track. It's followed by three interludes. "Be Alone" is more indie rock with an incredibly awkward melody that shambles around like a drunken embarrassment. The album closes with "Future", which is three minutes of interlude and four minutes of noise. The end.I have nothing against Paramore, but if this is the direction they'll continue to pursue, I won't be listening to them for much longer. Hopefully they will come to their senses and realize that rock music can both be fun and go in new directions - they succeeded wonderfully with "Still Into You", a song that should be played at weddings, parties and everywhere with sunlight. To summarize, 1.9 stars for "Still Into You", 0.1 stars for "Fast In My Car" and "Now". Use the rest as a coaster for a good beverage while you're listening to "Still Into You". That song rocks.
beauriful album. upbeat with undertones of depression. 5 stars however the first time you listen to it, you might think many songs sound the same but this wore off for me the second or third listen

Paramore's self-titled album sounds like their earliest work, but much more matured.  There is a lighter vibe to this selection, including three ukulele interludes that are a guilty pleasure to listen to.  "Fast In My Car" is an incredible opening number that is enjoyable to drive a sing with.  The single "Still Into You" is poignant and relevant.  My other favorite is "Ain't It Fun," which has the musicality of an anthem and appeals to all.  The other track in need of attention is "I Hate to See Your Heart Break," which is a truly different change of pace, but fits well in the track listings and can be enjoyed thoroughly.

review_title: Love the old style, and the new one too...
review_text: Paramore really went above and beyond on this album, the fact that they can completely change their style and still keep us satisfied is an amazing feat. I have a new found love and respect for the group. It legitimizes them as artists, rather then just a band. My favorite track is "Hate To See Your Heart Break", because it is such a change up and Haley's voice is wonderful. She is a great vocalist, and hot as hell. I love the new direction, keep up the great work guys...

I'm not gonna lie; when I started listened to this CD all the way through, I was thinking, "Huh. It's not bad, but it's not particularly good either." This was my feeling for the first three songs. They just didn't do it for me.That being said, WOW was I surprised when I found myself absolutely adoring every single other song on this album!!! From the free, catchy, fun strumming of "Moving On", to the furious energy on "Anklebiters", to the sexy hooks and symphonic features of "Crazy Girls", to the epic, crescendoing conclusion that is built-up in "Future", this album is a non-stop musical gem that I'm definitely going to want to sing along to in my car like an awkward lunatic.Well done, Paramore. You have truly impressed and enchanted what was once a casual listener and is now a devout follower. I wish you good luck and good times in all of your shows on tour. :)))

I did not keep all the songs on my iPod (these days that hardly happens, other than Lecrae's Gravity, Dead, Prez. Information Age, and Lupe Fiasco's food and liquor All FANTASTIC albums).I was super worried about Paramore's new self titled album, with new band members, and lack of original members, there's defiantly a new feel and style to this album, but I gotta' say I'M DIGGIN' IT!!!!!

review_title: I've never felt more connected to an album
review_text: I LOVE LOVE LOVE this album! I'm always nervous when I band I love changes their sound, but this is AMAZING. I love that the album is very much rooted in mental health. Ever feel like an album was written about your life? That is how I felt about After Laughter. It's like they watched my life for the last year and a half and wrote songs about it. I will forever play this on loop!
Interesting change. Really like some songs. Others not so much.

review_title: I loved the old sound of Paramore
review_text: I loved the old sound of Paramore... The bands forst 3 albums are mainstays in my music and played alot... once the lineup changed and they dropped their Signature Sound... now they sound like every POP band.. most of this songs have the same music.  Not sure if they will ever be a rock band that I will listen to again..  Definitely not going to go see them live again, they were amazing on the Brand New eyes tour evven though we all knew it was the end of the band with the Farros (the Farro drumming on this just is not the same)
Absolutely love it. The best part is once I bought it, the AudioRip kicked in and I got the MP3 as well. So when I got the CD, I had already had the album and fully enjoyed it.

I really liked Paramore since their start with their first album , "All We Know is Falling." They've grown a lot and lost two of their main members.... Still, even with that, this album is a little different from their old music but its very good! The music is mostly upbeat. My favorite song is "Grow Up." :)I recommend getting this album.
I love this band, and this album is so so good. Love it!!

review_title: Paramore takes a chance on different sounds, pays off
review_text: Everything about this album is flawless. The Paramore lineup has changed here so there was an opportunity to experiment. Hayley is not a 15 year old in a scene band anymore and naturally explored including elements of pop, country, and sometimes shoegaze on here. It all sounds fantastic. Hayley Williams has grown into this confident artist that isn't afraid to take her voice to another level and get listeners to dance. This album was released in 2013 but I am still recommending it to everyone. I hope the negative reviews will not deter Hayley and co. from recording what they want to play next time around.

I purchased this cd expecting the usual Paramore sound which I greatly enjoy but what I got was an incredibly beautiful and mature album.  From start to finish the lyrics and music just speak to my soul.  Hayley is bringing it and showing us that she isn't just a pretty girl fronting a band.  She has a versatile soulful sound that is evident all over the compilation and the band is playing their asses off.  The breakdown in the end of Future is a truly beautiful piece of music. Definitely a start to finish play and one I can listen to multiple times.

review_title: Different sound for the band, but still good
review_text: Paramore's self-titled fourth album is a strong follow up to the band's third release "Brand New Eyes". The band's sound has changed a bit. Not surprising, since the band's members have changed.  Instead of a straight pop-punk sound, elements of electronic rock, retro new wave, and indie pop have been incorporated into their usual sound.  I do miss the band's old sound a bit.  Hayley's irresistible attitude is less present and the youthful rebellion has weaned. But bands, especially pop-punk bands, have to grow up. And their new sound works well, and they haven't shed most of the things we've come to love about the band. The guitar riffs and percussion pack a punch, Hayley's voice is still awesome, and often the songs are catchy and have great energy.The lyrical content isn't as strong as their last album though.  The production of this album is their strongest, but the songwriting is a step down. "Brand New Eyes" has many reflective lyrics, but they are lacking on this album.The opener, "Fast In My Car", is a power-pop number the echoes girl-led 80s new wave bands.  "Now", the first single, is a edgy number that wouldn't be out of place on their last album. "Part II" is one of a few tracks where get experimental.  "Still Into You" is another power-pop number. "Anklebiters" is straight, unpolished pop-punk. "Hate To See Your Heart Break" is one of few ballads on the album. Like a few other tracks, it has an obvious influence of indie singer-songwriter Ingrid Michaelson.(4.25 out of 5 stars)--Isa R Bufano (05.09.2013)

Even after the departure of Jac and Zach Farro, Paramore was able to recreate some sounds of their past and experiment with some new ones. You'll get through the first 12 tracks in a breeze but the remaining 5 tracks didn't really stick well-- even after trying to listen to them multiple times. Nevertheless, the first 12 tracks are pretty much an entire album and deserve 5 stars for creativity and giving older fans what they want.

review_title: I like how they used their own name as the title
review_text: I am one of those fans who followed Paramore from when they were doing the all we know is falling album up until now, and I gotta tell you they're still slaying it after all these years. Sure, they altered their style in here, but, hey, it worked! The songs in this album are catchy. I like how they used their own name as the title, since it's like telling the world Paramore is still here to rock no mater what happened, still Paramore. At least, that's what it's like for me. For me, this is one of the best albums that they've done.

review_title: Paramore Is a Different Band, But Still Doesn't Disappoint and Never Will
review_text: Even though the Farros left after 'Brand New Eyes', Paramore still are a great band, and this album is proof. This album is new territory but also still has the same Paramore roots. In my opinion, every song is great, and this album really shows Paramore's growth. "Fast In My Car" is a great beginning for the record, still sounding like "Paramore" but being quite different at the same time. "Now" is a heavier track that is amazing, and was a great first taste of this record. "Grow Up" is much different from the usual, but has great lyrics and is very catchy. "Daydreaming" sounds like Paramore to me, and is very well-written and beautiful. The 3 interludes are quite catchy and different. "Ain't It Fun" is really funky with an amazing gospel choir at the end. "Part II" is much like Paramore, being the sequel to the RIOT! hit, "Let the Flames Begin." Personally my favorite track on the record. "Last Hope" is a beautiful, deep song that sounds much like the band we knew. "Still Into You" is a catchy, cute, bubbly pop love song. "Anklebiters" is a very meaningful, special song that is so well-written! It's as punk as punk can get. "Proof" is one of the best songs off here, in my opinion. The music is what makes it stand out from the other songs. "Hate to See Your Heart Break" is an amazing, slow song with violins, and it's no doubt one of Paramore's best slow songs. "One Of Those Crazy Girls" has a classy style but in a new form. It was a great idea by Paramore! "Be Alone" sounds much like Paramore, and has amazing verses! "Future" is a long, heavier song that is one of the best songs off here!So in all, this is Paramore's second best album in my opinion. If there's any other album that sounds like this one, it would definitely be RIOT! One of the best albums ever! Highly recommended.
Most people arn't a big fan of the "new" paramore but I absolutely LOVE it

Decided to randomly buy this at a hot topic today and I have to say its one of the better albums I've listened to this month definitely worth the money and if you buy vinyls like me you'll enjoy the unique vinyl color and excellent sound. c: give this one a 5 out of 5 for surprising me in the best way.
Awesome rock tunes! Paramore is the best! The track "no friend" was genius! Fake Happy is a killer, what an excellent work

I love all the songs in this album. This is not like their previous album but a lot of songs here are great. Personal favorites are: Rose-colored boy, Hard Times, Caught in the Middle, Pool, Forgiveness, and Tell Me How. I would recommend this album to everyone. Love you Hayley!

review_title: rock or pop but I do know it is absolutely brilliant. With Taylor York and Jeremy Davis
review_text: I don't know if this album is punk, rock or pop but I do know it is absolutely brilliant.  With Taylor York and Jeremy Davis, Hayley is better than ever and it is still one of the few groups that can out right get it!I purchased the 2 dics LP and in case you are wondering, it's much better quality that the CD or the MP3 version.

Okay im gonna admit it: I did not like this album the first time hearing it. There were some tracks i liked, but the whole thing just sounded wrong to me. If your an avid Paramore fan who's been listening since their "Riot!" days and were expecting their signature rock sound, you may have been disappointed too. But i really wanted to like this album, so i listened to the songs again and it began to grow on me and i realized that these songs are much more mature and grown up then their previous records, lyrically and musically. Their old records were lots of loud music and screaming about being angry, etc. These songs represent freedom and not being angry anymore and to grow up (hence the songs "Grow Up", and "I'm not angry anymore".) There are some songs i dont really care for (which is something rare when it comes to Paramore), but in general the songs aren't bad. not at all. It takes getting used to, but its really a fantastic record. Theres something for everyone, such as rock songs, pop songs, and even some ukulele in there. Here are my picks for this album:Now: An amazing song, this song is  relatable and catchy. Reminds me of Riot!Still into you: a lot of people didn't like this song, but its soooo catchy!!! its such a happy song.Interlude: Holday: the interludes are genius and Holiday talks about growing up and dealing with real problems and how when your stressed out you need a Vacation (or "holiday" as Paramore says it.Interlude: Moving on: this song is soo catchy and talks about moving on from an ex that is with someone else, that would never be the same as it was with them.Interlude: I'm not angry anymore: this song talks about being not angry at someone. this song could be interpreted as anything. (such as an ex, or friends, etc)Last Hope: At first i didn't like this song, but now its one of my favorites from the record. This song talks about having that last glimmer of hope to keep you going.Grow up: this song talks about growing up in life, even if it means having to lose people while doing it.Part II: This song is a sequel to one of my fave paramore songs "let the flames begin". at first i did not like it, but now its growing on me.Anklebiters: this song talks about not caring about the haters and is a rock song (like Riot!)Hate to see your heart break: this song is a slow acoustic song about feeling sad when someone you care about is sadEscape Route: this song is a bonus track on the japanese version of the album. Which is a shame since this is an epic song. Its about trying to live your dreams, and not paying attetion to how hard the present is.

WHERE HAVE PARAMORE GONE...? Those 2 boys who left seem to have been what made Paramore good. Hailey's voice is still great, but the music is like some 80s throwback rubbish. Why do bands think changing from why people liked you originally is somehow better than just being what people liked about you in the first place, like it gives them more integrety or sonmething? The most successful bands of all time. Metallica, U2, The Stones, they didn't change their style and look where they are. Also I cant think of one band that did change that hasn't disappeared.
The only album i can get into from them.Would definitely recommend.
Came at a really rough time for me, but I really appreciate this album now. Five Stars :)

review_title: The guitar and drums have excellent hooks throughout the album
review_text: So many people are holding on to the past sound of Paramore... this is a step in the right direction of where music is heading. The lyrical matter is relevant. The guitar and drums have excellent hooks throughout the album. Haley's vocals are extraordinary as always. This album greatly showcases the talent of these three individuals.

Every time I go for a drive, I can't help but put on the song "Fast in My Car". There seems to be an atmosphere in this album, as if they're  opening up their bottled-up thoughts that have been around for awhile. I find it to be a fantastic album worth checking out.

So, despite being a long-time fan, this album is where I get off of train Paramore.  Like another reviewer, the genre change isn't the problem.  The problem is that there isn't a single track on this album that has any energy or excitement, or that stands out in any way.  I had hoped that the return of the long-time drummer would bring back a little more energy than what was featured on the last album, but it just isn't there.  If anything, the drummer is almost completely wasted here.  A stunning disappointment from a band I have been a fan of for a long time.

What else needs to be said that hasn't been? This self-titled fuses some pop elements with their signature punk/rock style albums of the past and the result is an album that I have hard time believing they could top.

I really love Still Into You so I thought I'd go ahead and buy it even though I've never bought a Paramore album. I've always sort of liked some of their songs but never enough to buy an album and I guess now I'm realizing why. I personally would give it less than three stars but I'm trying to be fair since I'm sure there are many who will love it. I just hate feeling a little disappointed with my music purchases and that's what I'm feeling right now as I eject it from my CD player.
Grandson’ s present.

review_title: From A Die Hard Paramore Fan...
review_text: Ok, so everyone's going on and on about how Paramore has changed for the worse and they are more pop and blahblahblah.  Is this true?  Yes and no.  But overall, this CD will have you moving and listening to it over and over.  I've loved Paramore since they first came out, and I have to say that this CD has some of the best songs ever created by them.  Songs like "Part II", "Anklebiters", and "Proof", travel back more to their roots and fans of Paramore will instantly fall in love with them.  Other songs like "Ain't it fun" don't have the traditional Paramore feel, but its important to recognize that this is still amazing music.  They have evolved and matured as a band, and as such some of their music has evolved as well.  If you buy the CD you will see what I mean.  Don't get me wrong, this CD will never be RIOT!, but it definitely is worth listening to and I would go so far to say that not listening to it would be a slight against yourself.
